    Discovery of New H2S Releasing Phosphordithioates and 2,3-Dihydro-2-phenyl-2-sulfanylenebenzo[d][1,3,2]oxazaphospholes with Improved Antiproliferative Activity

    • Wei Feng†‡
      • , 
    • Xin-Yi Teo‡
      • , 
    • Wisna Novera§
      • , 
    • Pondy Murugappan Ramanujulu†‡
      • , 
    • Dong Liang∥
      • , 
    • Dejian Huang∥
      • , 
    • Philip K. Moore‡⊥
      • , 
    • Lih-Wen Deng§
      • , and 
    • Brian W. Dymock*†
    View Author Information
    † Department of Pharmacy, National University of Singapore, Block S4A Level 3, 18 Science Drive 4, Singapore 117543
    ‡ Life Sciences Institute, Centre for Life Sciences, National University of Singapore, Level 5, 28 Medical Drive, Singapore 117456
    § Department of Biochemistry, National University of Singapore, Block MD7 04-06, 8 Medical Drive, Singapore 117596
    ∥ Department of Chemistry, National University of Singapore, Block S8 Level 3, Science Drive 3, Singapore 117543

    SUBJECTS:
    • Cancer therapy,
    • Phosphorus,
    • Assays,
    • Cells,
    • Probes
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) is now recognized as a physiologically important gasotransmitter. Compounds which release H2S slowly are sought after for their potential in therapy. Herein the synthesis of a series of phosphordithioates based on 1 (GYY4137) are described. Their H2S release profiles are characterized using 2,6-dansyl azide (2), an H2S specific fluorescent probe. Most compounds have anticancer activity in several solid tumor cell lines and are less toxic in a normal human lung fibroblast, WI38. A preferred compound, 14, with 10-fold greater anticancer activity than 1, was shown to release H2S in MCF7 cells using a cell active probe, 21. Both permeability and intracellular pH (pHi) were found to be significantly improved for 14 compared to 1. Furthermore, 14 was also negative in the AMES test for genotoxicity. Cyclization of these initial structures gave a series of 2,3-dihydro-2-phenyl-2-sulfanylenebenzo[d][1,3,2]oxazaphospholes, of which the simplest member, compound 22 (FW1256), was significantly more potent in cells. The improved therapeutic window of 22 in WI38 cells was compared with three other cell types. Potency of 22 was superior to 1 in MCF7 tumor spheroids and the mechanism of cell death was shown to be via apoptosis with an increase in cleaved PARP and activated caspase-7. Evidence of H2S release in cells is also presented. This work provides a “toolbox” of slow-release H2S donors useful for studies of H2S in biology and as potential therapeutics in cancer, inflammation, and cardiovascular disease.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) at high concentrations is a toxic, malodorous gas, however, at low concentrations, H2S is increasingly recognized as an important cell-signaling gasotransmitter, the so-called “third gasotransmitter”, after the extensively studied carbon monoxide and nitric oxide.(1, 2) H2S is produced endogenously via enzymatic reactions of cysteine, homocysteine, and cystathionine mediated by cystathionine-β-synthase (CBS) and cystathionine-γ-lyase (CSE).(3) Furthermore, a third enzyme specific to the mitochondria, 3-mercaptopyruvate sulfurtransferase (3-MST), has been identified to produce H2S.(4)
    In the past decade, H2S has been shown to play significant roles in physiology and pathology including cardioprotection,(5-7) inflammation,(8-10) atherosclerosis,(11, 12) neuromodulation,(13) hypertension,(14) hemorrhagic shock,(15) pain perception,(16, 17) and gastric mucosal integrity.(18) In cancer, H2S has been shown to trigger apoptosis via activation of MAP kinase and caspase-3,(19) sulfhydration of NF-κB(20) and H2S donors have reported antiangiogenic(21, 22) effects with phosphorylation of the protein kinase Akt being implicated.(23) Furthermore, the PI3K-Akt pathway was also shown to be activated in cardioprotective studies of H2S. However, to date, the mechanisms of action of the effects of H2S have only been partially elucidated. Kimura has reported that H2S protects cells from oxidative stress via enhancing the production of glutathione (GSH) by increasing the transport of cysteine.(24, 25) It has also been suggested that H2S may suppress oxidative stress directly as an antioxidant.(24) Recently, it has been shown that mitochondrial targeting of H2S has a powerful antioxidant effect.(26) H2S has been reported to regulate protein function via protein S-sulfhydration (protein-S-SH), adding to the “persulfide pool” of which some of the main players are S-cysteine and S-glutathione at levels up to 100 μM.(20, 27-29) Conversely, there are also reports of the opposing effects of H2S, where, for example, inhibition of its production appears to be of benefit.(30) Such a wide range of physiological studies clearly implicate H2S as an important factor in disease. Therapeutically focused mechanistic studies are hampered by the limited availability of “controllable” and “drug-like” H2S donors, defined as compounds with a useful range of known H2S release rates under physiological conditions. Sodium sulfide (Na2S) and sodium hydrogen sulfide (NaHS) salts, giving virtually instant generation of H2S upon dissolution and hydrolysis by water, are still frequently used in biological studies. Compared to these inorganic salts, organic H2S donors are able to release H2S slowly and continuously at low concentrations similar to endogenous levels. There are several classes of such organic H2S donors, based on diverse mechanisms of H2S release, which have been developed to date (Figure 1).(26, 31-35)
    Among these compounds, GYY4137 (1) is one of the most extensively studied organic H2S donors with a wide range of biological activities, both in oncology and nononcology, having been reported in over 50 publications to date.(36, 37) Therapeutic applications of 1 range from cardiovascular to inflammation and aging to cancer.(38-46) In oncology, Deng and co-workers reported that 1 exhibits anticancer activity in vitro without significantly affecting normal cells.(39, 47) In support of H2S donors as potential therapeutics, Deng also demonstrated the anticancer effect of 1 in a mouse model of cancer.(39) It was found that this anticancer activity was also H2S-concentration dependent. Lu and co-workers have shown that 1 has promising activity in hepatocellular cancer through blocking STAT3.(48) Recently, Deng and co-workers have reported that continuous exposure of cells to H2S by dosing the short-lived NaHS salt every 2 h mimics the effects of the slow releasing 1, whereas a single dose of NaHS has no effect. Prolonged exposure to H2S by dosing cells with a single dose of 1 led to intracellular acidification via increased glycolysis and deregulation of cellular pH control.(47) All of these findings support the critical requirement for appropriate H2S concentrations to be delivered at a suitable rate to exert a physiologic effect without toxicity. To further study the relationship between H2S concentrations and anticancer biological activity, we herein report the design and synthesis of a series of dithiophosphorus H2S donors based on 1. These compounds display a wide range of H2S release profiles and antiproliferative activities. By varying the nucleophiles employed in the synthesis, it is possible to control the reactivity of the compounds, thus tuning the H2S release rate. Such a related series of tool compounds, within the same molecular series, delivering a broad range of H2S concentrations over hours to days, have not been previously reported and may lead to deeper understanding of H2S cellular mechanisms and potentially to new therapeutics for unmet medical needs. We also show that a preferred compound, 14, has an order of magnitude improvement in antiproliferative activity compared to 1 while retaining a therapeutic window over normal cells, lowers intracellular pH (pHi) to a greater extent than 1, and increases intracellular H2S levels. We also describe further development of the series via cyclization which leads to a new series of 2,3-dihydro-2-phenyl-2-sulfanylenebenzo[d][1,3,2]oxazaphospholes. A preferred compound, 22, has increased potency toward solid tumor cells while being nontoxic to WI38 cells at the highest concentration tested. Taken together, this work provides new H2S donor compounds, with a wide range of H2S release rates, and takes a step toward a potential H2S therapy for the treatment of cancer.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    In Vitro Quantification of H2S Released from 1 (GYY4137)

    Application and optimization of a recently described fluorescent probe for quantification of slow-release H2S evolved directly from 1 and its novel analogues is herein described. However, such probes are still only indirectly quantifying H2S evolved from donor compounds following the necessary reduction reaction of the probe by H2S. Hence we also explored the direct detection of H2S by headspace GC-MS, which does not involve any chemical transformations to achieve a readout.
    Until the recent development of new H2S selective probes, there have been few practical methods suitable to detect the low levels of H2S evolved from therapeutic compounds. A detailed study of the H2S release profile of 1 over a period of days, the time course of many of the aforementioned therapeutic studies, is essential for a better understanding of its activities. Current techniques for H2S detection described in the literature include colorimetric(49, 50) and electrochemical assays,(51) gas chromatography,(52) metal-induced sulfide precipitation,(53) and the most sensitive and probably most accurate method yet reported using HPLC.(54, 55) The latter method, although complex to carry out, is being applied by Kevil to study H2S levels in the clinic.(56, 57) These techniques often require significant sample processing, hence estimates of H2S concentrations can be highly variable and potentially unreliable, especially without expert guidance. For the quantification of H2S released from dithiophosphorus compounds, such as 1, we required a robust and easy to carry out method for routine laboratory application. A methylene blue assay has been employed for H2S detection, however, hydrochloric acid, which can significantly accelerate the H2S release rate, is required in the system, potentially resulting in errors in the measured H2S concentrations.(54) Many fluorescent probes(58-70) have been developed recently, some are very recently published and have not yet been evaluated by other groups. Among these probes, 2,6-dansyl azide (2, Figure 2), reported by Wang in 2014,(62) reacts with H2S in a few minutes to generate a fluorescent product with a higher quantum yield compared to the previously published 1,5-dansyl azide probe (3).(69)
    Following extensive attempts to synthesize and apply a suitable probe for the detection of H2S specifically from 1, we were encouraged by promising initial results with probe 2. The 1,5-dansyl azide alternative probe can also be used, but 2 is more sensitive with lower background. We proceeded to optimize simple cell-free in vitro assay conditions for monitoring of H2S release from 1 over a period of days with probe 2. We prepared both 1 and 2 as per the reported procedures with one modification in the synthesis of 2 (see Supporting Information).
    Compound 1 is an ionic salt, and its solubility is generally low in most organic solvents. Probe 2 is a lipophilic organic compound and is not soluble under aqueous conditions. Thus, to completely dissolve both components as close as possible to physiological conditions, a balance of organic and aqueous solvent is required. A mixture of acetonitrile (MeCN) and phosphate buffered saline (PBS) at pH 7.4 was chosen for initial studies. We first investigated the stability of 2 with different volume ratios of PBS:MeCN over 4 days, a time period of particular relevance to the study of slow H2S releasers. With more than 70% PBS, the probe is not soluble. When PBS is less than 10%, the media is not clear due to precipitation of phosphate salts. Hence probe stability over time was carried out with PBS:MeCN ratios ranging from 10% to 30%. Background fluorescence response units increased with increases in PBS:MeCN ratios (Figure 3).
    Stability of 2 was also tested in pH 3.0 PBS, however, a clear solution is not possible to obtain at this pH, and inconsistent results were obtained. Hence we settled on 10% PBS:MeCN as the media for further studies. Next we wanted to understand application of this probe in media with additional components found in cells at their physiological concentrations. Reliable quantification of H2S inside living cells is still very challenging. Nevertheless, we wanted to understand if 2 could potentially be used for assessment of intracellular levels of H2S released from 1. It has been reported that probe 2 is stable in 100 μM glutathione (GSH) or cysteine. However, we found that 2 reacts with physiological (millimolar) levels of GSH or cysteine under the optimized assay conditions. When 2 was incubated with GSH or cysteine, fluorescence response increased significantly, particularly for added cysteine, indicating that 2 is not selective for H2S quantification with physiological concentrations of added biological thiols. (Supporting Information Figure S88). Notwithstanding these limitations, we have found that 2 is applicable in situations where lower levels of such thiols are present such as in cell media.(71)
    Having established the optimal solvent conditions for probe stability, we next determined the H2S release profile of standard solutions of sodium sulfide (Na2S). Salts such as Na2S or NaHS, both commonly used in the H2S literature, rapidly hydrolyze in water, releasing H2S within seconds into the solution. Solutions of Na2S with 2 were freshly prepared from dried solid sodium sulfide salt (nonahydrate) added directly to a solution of 2 (0.2 mM) in the optimized solvent 9:1 MeCN:PBS at room temperature. A direct correlation between Na2S levels and fluorescence response units (RU) was observed, enabling a calibration equation to be established relating fluorescence RU to concentration of H2S, applicable to the analysis of H2S releasing drugs (Figure 4A).
    This calibration applies only to experiments using 0.2 mM of 2. If a different concentration of 2 is used, a separate calibration should be determined, for example, with 1 mM of 2 (Figure 4B). With a calibration in hand we next determined the H2S release profile of compound 1 at 22 °C (Figure 5A). Three concentrations were studied to reflect conditions in typical published pharmacological studies with up to 5 mM concentration of 1:(72) 0.2, 1, and 5 mM, tested in triplicate, thrice (total N = 9).
    At the lower concentration of 0.2 mM of 1, lower amounts of H2S was detected, near to the limit of detection of the assay (approximately 1 μM). When the concentration of 1 was increased to 1 mM, 7.5 ± 0.6 μM of H2S was detected after 4 days. Increasing the concentration of 1 to 5 mM, 49.4 ± 3.5 μM of H2S was quantified after 5 days at room temperature. About 10 μM of H2S was released every day, showing a steady release profile suitable for an H2S therapeutic. However, given the lower concentrations of 1 required to observe inhibition of cancer cell proliferation (IC50 approximately 350 μM in MCF7 cells), it is likely that (i) H2S release rates may be higher in cells due to enhanced release from cellular components, (ii) the higher temperature in cells may increase H2S release rates, and (iii) the probe sensitivity may be too low.
    To study the influence of temperature on H2S rate, a similar analysis was carried out at 37 °C at the same three concentrations (Figure 5B). At 0.2 mM, 1 again released trace amounts of H2S. When the concentration of 1 was increased to 1 mM, a 4.7-fold higher amount of H2S was detected at 37 °C than at 22 °C after 4 days of incubation. When the concentration of 1 was further increased to 5 mM, a surprisingly large amount of H2S (0.8 mM), 16-fold greater than at 22 °C, was detected after a 4 day incubation at 37 °C. Note that 1 mM of probe 2 was required for quantification of the higher levels of evolved H2S at 5 mM concentration of 1. Regardless of any nonlinear effects between probe responses at 0.2 and 1.0 mM concentrations, this is a higher than expected evolution of H2S at 37 °C, which may explain the reported cellular and in vivo pharmacology of 1, i.e., 1 may be releasing more H2S in living systems than expected from its in vitro behavior, potentially due to the higher temperature in cells compared to “room temperature”. Given the high sensitivity of the H2S release to temperature, future experiments were conducted with a sample of 1 as a control.
    Having established the H2S release profile of 1 with fluorescent probe 2, we wanted to provide additional direct evidence for the release of H2S from 1. Hence we employed head space GC-MS (HS-GC-MS) to find evidence for the presence of H2S gas, thus proving that 1 is able to release H2S.(73) Under the assay conditions used for 2 (5 mM 1 in 9:1 MeCN:PBS), the mass of H2S, 34, was indeed observed. Unfortunately, under the conditions, it was quite weak compared to strong signals for MeCN and oxygen. Dissolving 1 in pure PBS at 5 mM solved the MeCN interference, but oxygen was still a problem. We were also concerned that H2S, being extremely volatile, was escaping from the solution and the headspace before a sample could be taken. Hence a solution of 1 was dissolved in PBS and placed in a microwave tube, which can be sealed gastight. After sealing, the tube was vacuumed to remove oxygen (see experimental section). Thus, when H2S was evolved from 1, its concentration in the headspace was significantly higher so as to enable detection (Figure 6). Thus, we confirmed qualitatively the release of H2S from 1.
    In summary, utilizing recently reported probe 2, we have optimized a straightforward assay for H2S quantification from the slow releasing H2S donor drug, 1, over a period of up to 4 or 5 days. Longer incubation times are also possible with this method. Probe 2 is stable under neutral conditions with 10% aqueous phase, enabling the H2S release profile of 1 to be determined. Furthermore, we have proven that H2S is indeed released from 1 using HS-GC-MS technology. With the desired practical, robust assay in hand, we next prepared a number of direct analogues of 1, aiming to identify a series of compounds with a range of H2S release profiles and improved antiproliferative activity.

    Design and Synthesis of Compounds

    Until recently, when a series of 5 O-substituted N-phenyl phosphordithioates, with only oxygen and nitrogen phosphorus substituents (Figure 1), were reported,(74) to our knowledge, morpholine-substituted 1 was the only reported phosphordithioate based derivative characterized in a biological system. These reported O,N-phosphordithioates, with variations in their structures only in the substituents, not directly on atoms bonded to phosphorus, have very similar H2S release rates, so we hypothesized that variations distal to the phosphorus were unlikely to change the hydrolysis reactivity of similar compounds. Given this and the wide range of applications of compound 1, we wanted to further explore carbon–phosphorus based phosphordithioates with the aim to understand the role of the substituents, both directly attached and distal to the phosphorus, in controlling the release rates of H2S, assuming a predominantly water hydrolysis mechanism (Supporting Information Figure 89).(37) We selected 1 as our lead compound due to its reported drug-like properties, which gave us reason to believe that this structural class holds particular promise for eventual development of a H2S donor clinical candidate.
    Direct analogues of 1 were prepared by ring-opening of Lawesson’s Reagent (LR) in dichloromethane at room temperature, similar to the previously described procedure.(37) As well as amines used as per the synthesis of 1,(7) phenols and alcohols were employed as nucleophiles (Table 1).
    Table 1. Synthesis and 31P NMR Chemical Shifts of H2S Donor Compounds
    Table a

    With the exception of compounds 8, 9, 12 and 14.

    Table b

    Isolated as a zwitterion.

    Table c

    Isolated as a benzylamine salt.

    Products were precipitated from the reaction mixtures by adding morpholine, or another amine, to form ionic salts which could be purified by filtration, washing, and drying. This process was not successful with all attempted reactions (see experimental section). For some nucleophiles, like anilines, pyrazole, and thiophenols, no precipitation occurred. Carbon nucleophiles also did not give desired products. All of the isolated compounds were characterized with 1H, 13C, 31P NMR, LRMS, and/or HR ESI mass spectroscopy and HPLC analysis. To confirm our NMR assignments, the molecular structure of isopropoxy compound 10 was determined via single crystal X-ray structure analysis. This structure clearly indicated a tetrahedral phosphorus with attached isopropoxy and methoxyphenyl groups, with morpholine as the counterion (Figure 7), confirming the structural assignments.
    With these compounds, H2S is released most probably through hydrolysis by water. Therefore, it is expected that the electrophilicity of the phosphorus atom will greatly affect the hydrolysis-mediated H2S release rate. Hence, modifying the electron density of the phosphorus atom by varying the nature of the nucleophile should lead to changes in hydrolysis rate and hence rate of H2S generation. Both electron-donating (compound 7) and electron-withdrawing (compound 6) phenols were successfully employed in the synthesis. Alkyl alcohols (compounds 4, 10, 11, 15 and 16) were used to further broaden the electrophilicity range of the phosphorus atom. Compared to the 31P NMR shift of 1 (89 ppm) and other amine nucleophiles, compounds derived from alkyl alcohols and phenols had 31P NMR shifts in the range 102–112 ppm. Considering the expected large downfield shift when oxygen is replaced by sulfur, these chemical shifts are in the expected range.(8) Compared with 1, the further downfield chemical shift of P–O compounds (compounds 4–11 and 15–16) is likely due to the increased electronegativity of the oxygen atom, increasing the positive charge on phosphorus and in turn increasing back-bonding from the sulfur which is associated with the upfield shift displayed.(9) The electron-withdrawing (e.g., 111.90 ppm for 6) and electron-donating (e.g., 107.39 ppm for 7) substituted phenols only slightly affect the 31P NMR chemical shift due to the strong proximity of the electronegative oxygen compared to the rather distant placement of the substituent. Compared to phenols, alkyl alcohol nucleophiles led to upfield chemical shifts of 102–108 ppm. The effect of substituents directly attached to the phosphorus atom were also studied by changing the methoxy (OMe) group to a phenoxy (OPh) group using Belleau’s reagent. The range of available Lawesson’s Reagent (LR) derivatives is extremely limited, hence we have not yet expanded our studies of substituents of this aryl ring. However, using Belleau’s reagent, four phenoxyphenyl derivatives bearing amine and alkyl alcohol groups were prepared (compounds 13–16). The phenoxy group did not significantly affect the 31P NMR shifts for alcohols (compare 15 with 4 and 16 with 10) and only slightly for morpholine (compare 13 with 1). In addition to the two tertiary amine morpholine derivatives, two secondary amines were also prepared with benzylamine, compounds 12 and 14, both with very similar 31P chemical shifts but significantly shifted well below 90 ppm compared to the oxygen substituted derivatives. The range of 31P chemical shifts achieved with this group of compounds was expected to lead to differences in their reactivity and H2S release rates. These rates were next characterized using the optimized assay with probe 2.

    Quantification of Evolved H2S in Vitro and Rate of Release

    Having these compounds in hand, we turned our attention to the determination of their H2S release rates in the optimized PBS:MeCN buffer system. Generally, these compounds release H2S very slowly, ideal for biological applications, hence the parent compounds must be studied at high concentrations. At concentrations of 0.2 mM, H2S is barely detectable in this system in most cases of slow release compounds. At 1 mM compound concentrations, released H2S is quantifiable with many slow release compounds. However, only when the compounds were tested at the highest concentration of 5 mM could significant amounts of H2S be detected and quantified. Either derived from Lawesson’s Reagent or Belleau’s reagent, all compounds bearing phenol nucleophiles (5, 6, and 7) released around 20 μM H2S after a four-day incubation at 22 °C (Figure 8A and Table 2).
    Table 2. Summary of H2S Quantification Data
    compdcompd concn (mM)H2S release categoryaH2S release (μM, 22 °C)bpercentage of theoretical maximum H2S released (22 °C) (%)H2S release (μM, 37 °C)bpercentage of theoretical maximum H2S released (37 °C) (%) ratio of 37/22 °Cnormalized H2S release (22 °C)fnormalized H2S release (37 °C)f
    15medium143 ± 101.43614 ± 82d6.144.31.01.0
    45low5.9 ± 0.240.0615 ± 1.20.152.5<0.1<0.1
    55low21 ± 0.740.2141 ± 2.20.412.00.10.1
    65low22 ± 1.70.2231 ± 2.40.311.40.20.1
    75low19 ± 0.850.1931 ± 2.80.311.60.10.1
    85low<0.012.7 ± 0.780.032.7e <0.1

    blank  1.0 ± 0.1b 1.9 ± 0.23b

         6.9 ± 0.32c    
    a

    Release rates classified as low (<50 μM H2S over 96 h at 5 mM), medium (>50 μM H2S over 96 h at 5 mM or <50 μM H2S over 48 h at 0.5 mM), high (>50 μM H2S over 48 h at 0.5 mM).

    b

    Assay at 5 mM compound using 0.2 mM probe at 96 h.

    c

    0.5 mM compound with 1 mM probe at 48 h.

    d

    5 mM compound using 1 mM probe at 96 h.

    e

    Taken as a ratio of the blank.

    f

    Normalized to compound 1.

    g

    Compd 1 used as blank (12 μM).

    h

    Compd 1 used as blank (6.9 μM). Data for compd 1 was taken from assays conducted in the same plates as the other compounds and on average was about 3-fold higher [H2S] at room temperature compared to the earlier experiments during assay development.

    When the temperature was increased to physiological levels, 37 °C (Figure 9A), approximately 31–41 μM H2S was detected from 5, 6, and 7 after 4 days, representing less than 0.5% of the theoretical maximum amount of available H2S from these compounds.
    However, compounds derived from alkyl alcohols (4, 9, 10, 11, 15, and 16) released much less H2S, only 2.3–6 μM at 22 °C (Figure 8A and Table 2) and 6.1–16 μM at 37 °C (Figure 9A and Table 2), only up to 0.16% of available sulfur. Derived from Belleau’s reagent, 15 and 16 released a similar amount of H2S to their LR-derived counterparts, 4 and 10. Compound 8, bearing an ethylaminoethoxy side chain, did not release any detectable H2S after 4 days at 22 °C and was only just quantifiable at 37 °C. This may due to an electrostatic intramolecular interaction forming a six-membered ring between the positively charged nitrogen atom and negatively charged sulfur atom, reducing the conformational freedom and reactivity of the phosphorus center. Compounds 13 and 14, which were derived from Belleau’s reagent and amine nucleophiles morpholine and benzylamine, respectively, and the corresponding LR-derived 1 and 12, released about 5–6-fold more H2S than the alcohol/phenol derived compounds at 22 °C, equating to approximately 1.2–2.2% of the theoretical maximum amount of H2S (Figure 8B). When 1, 12, 13, and 14 were tested at 37 °C, a 2.2–3.3-fold increase in accumulated H2S was detected at the end of the 4-day assay period, equating to between 281 and 554 μM H2S, which is comparable with that of 1 (614 μM) and representing 2.8–5.5% of theoretical available sulfur (Figure 9B). The aforementioned higher increase for 1 going from 22 to 37 °C may be one reason why compound 1 has found so many applications in biological systems. The question as to what is the “ideal” H2S release profile for a H2S donor compound will probably depend on a multitude of factors, not just temperature. Intracellular permeability of the compound, pH sensitivity, and subcellular localization are all relevant factors to consider as well as the underlying biological effects of the molecular scaffold as a whole. We were interested in whether the compounds were entering cells or remaining in the extracellular matrix, hence we measured permeability of a number of compounds using the parallel artificial membrane permeability assay (PAMPA) (see below).
    Encouraged by this range of H2S release profiles from dithiophosphorus derivatives bearing one carbon and one heteroatom, we next explored increased combined electronegativity of the atoms attached to phosphorus. Compounds bearing two heteroatoms on phosphorus fulfilled this objective. A series of compounds were synthesized from P4S10 in a one step protocol (compounds 17–20, Table 3).
    Table 3. Synthesis and 31P NMR Chemical Shifts of Faster-Releasing H2S Donor Compounds
    Simply mixing P4S10 with amines, isolable products precipitate after stirring for a period of time. Pure products can be obtained by filtration and washing. These products are quite hydrophilic and degrade quite rapidly, hence were kept under dry conditions. For example, 20 will become sticky even when exposed to air for less than 1 h. As expected, these compounds have 31P NMR chemical shifts at around 0 ppm, significantly upfield of compounds in Table 1. When compounds 17–20 were incubated at one-tenth the concentration of the less reactive compounds, 0.5 mM, at 22 and 37 °C, a rapid release of H2S was detected. In particular, tertiary amines 18 and 20 were very rapid releasers of H2S, producing 672 and 485 μM, respectively, at 22 °C after only 2 days (Figure 10A and Table 2).
    At 37 °C, the amounts of H2S produced were even larger, representing 76.2 and 62.6% of the theoretical maximums for 18 and 20, respectively (Figure 10B). At the lower concentration of 0.1 mM, a significant amount of H2S, around 20% and 5% of the theoretical maxima, respectively, were detected for compounds 18 and 20 at 37 °C (Figure 10C). The H2S amount for these compounds does not significantly increase after 48 h. These compounds are hydrolyzed much faster than LR derived compounds, which is consistent with earlier results with carbon–phosphorus compounds. Although slower releasers than 18 and 20, secondary amines 17 and 19 still produced substantial amounts of H2S, 82 and 24 μM, respectively, at 22 °C. Note that these compounds were only tested at 0.5 mM concentration, ten times lower than the compounds of Table 1. At 37 °C, 17 released a 2.7-fold higher amount of H2S compared to the levels quantified at 22 °C, however, benzylamine 19 did not appear to release more H2S at the higher temperature. For the medium releasing compounds, two further concentrations were selected for further characterization of their H2S release profiles at concentrations where the compounds are used in cells (0.2 and 0.4 mM). Good dose responses were observed with levels of H2S ranging from 4.14 ± 0.40 μM for 13 at 0.2 mM to 17.19 ± 0.63 μM for 14 at 0.4 mM. This data highlights a useful level of control over H2S levels that is possible with these compounds.
    We hypothesized that the 31P chemical shifts may correlate with the observed levels of H2S. Analysis of the results indicate that, in general, compounds with upfield 31P NMR chemical shifts release more H2S over 4 days than those with downfield shifts (Figure 11). Note that compounds 17–20 were tested at one-tenth the concentration of the other compounds, hence the effect indicated in Figure 11 would probably be even more pronounced if the compounds were all tested under identical conditions.
    Shielding of the phosphorus nuclei, leading to a reduction in chemical shift, is increased by more electronegative substituents, a phenomenon thought to be due to increased back-bonding between P–X compared with P–C.(75, 76) Changes in P-shielding are most dramatic by varying the directly attached nuclei. The ability to control P-shielding offers an opportunity to the medicinal chemist to tune other molecular properties by varying substituents distal to the phosphorus center, which should not grossly affect the H2S release but can change other important properties such as permeability and solubility. Conformational effects, such as restricted rotation, could also be a factor in the overall performance of a compound: note that the higher releasing compounds 18 and 20 are both more bulky tertiary amines. Progression of an optimized H2S releasing therapeutic could benefit from such knowledge.
    Having established a group of tool compounds with varying rates of H2S release, we next set out to determine their biological activity in cancer cell proliferation assays.

    Biological Evaluation in Living Cells

    Compound 1 has been established as antiproliferative against solid tumor cells, albeit with weak potency. However, 1 has also been shown to be efficacious in a mouse model of cancer supporting the drug-like nature of this class of compounds.(39) Hence compounds 4–20 were tested against a range of proliferating solid tumor cell lines representing breast (MCF7, MBA-MD231), ovarian (SKOV3), and prostate (PC3) cancers. Several different assay methodologies were employed to ensure the observed phenotypes were consistent and not dependent on the method (Table 4 and Figure 12).
    Table 4. IC50 (μM) for Cell Proliferation Inhibition of Compounds in Different Cancer Cell Lines and One Normal Cell Line
    compdH2S release categoryaMCF7 (crystal violet) IC50 (μM)MCF7 (MTS) IC50 (μM)SKOV3 (crystal violet) IC50 (μM)MBA-MD231 (MTT) IC50 (μM)PC3 (MTT) IC50 (μM)WI38 (crystal violet) IC50 (μM)therapeutic indexc
    1medium368.2 ± 0.7>500332.0 ± 4.6239.6 ± 6.6>2001977 ± 193.35.4–8.2
    4low449.6 ± 3.1445.9 ± 77430 ± 0.9216.3 ± 17>200NDbNDb
    5low194.5 ± 3.7187.8 ± 33209.9 ± 2.764.5 ± 1.2NDd205.7 ± 3.21.0–3.2
    6low105.1 ± 1.4114.4 ± 2.4124.4 ± 0.540.37 ± 27.5ND202.6 ± 1.91.6–5.0
    7low162.6 ± 1.2242.5 ± 8.8177.4 ± 2.075.9 ± 13.7ND>400>2.2–5.3
    8low>400481.1 ± 27>400>500NDNDbNDb
    9low>400>500>400>500NDNDbNDb
    10low266.3 ± 6.4204.6 ± 68200.2 ± 0.484.6 ± 0.8ND>400>1.5–4.7
    11low92.0 ± 0.3192.6 ± 96ND77.6 ± 2179.1176.9 ± 2.91.1–2.3
    12medium84.2 ± 3.082.4 ± 17.689.9 ± 0.441.1 ± 4.331.9207.8 ± 0.32.3–6.5
    13medium194.7 ± 1.7163.2 ± 71326.4 ± 6.495.2 ± 14.6102.1655.9 ± 2.02.0–6.6
    14medium36.3 ± 2.167.6 ± 9.447.0 ± 2.155.4 ± 16.545.6103.9 ± 0.31.5–2.9
    15low180.8 ± 2.9201.8 ± 37164.9 ± 4.187 ± 42.373.1346.7 ± 6.71.9–6.1
    16low51.4 ± 1.5177.8 ± 5050.2 ± 0.1494.8 ± 5150.872.8 ± 0.571.4–1.5
    17high171.7 ± 6.2>500178.7 ± 13.0>500ND287.2 ± 17.4<1.0–1.7
    18high220.7 ± 10.0331.1 ± 239266.8 ± 18.7381.1 ± 168ND682.8 ± 5.52.6–3.1
    19medium144.6 ± 11.2218.4 ± 21189.4 ± 5.5104 ± 30ND265.7 ± 24.41.4–2.6
    20high20.4 ± 0.2 15.8 ± 1.9 ND30.4 ± 0.41.5–1.9
    a

    See Table 3.

    b

    IC50 not obtained for WI38 due to high IC50 for cell growth inhibition in cancer cells (MCF7 and SKOV3).

    c

    WI38/most and least sensitive cell lines.

    d

    ND = not determined.

    In general, compound 1 is a weak inhibitor of proliferation with IC50s ranging from 240 to >500 μM. In the previously reported cell proliferation assay using crystal violet,(6)1 had IC50s of 368 and 332 μM for MCF7 and SKOV3 cells, respectively. Most of the compounds show good agreement between the two different formats used for MCF7 assessment, crystal violet and MTT.(77) There appeared to be no direct correlation between H2S release rate or quantity of H2S released and inhibition of proliferation. No detectable inhibition of cell proliferation was observed with zwitterionic compounds 8 and 9, probably due to both their very polar nature leading to poor permeability and their low H2S release levels. These polar compounds give support to the hypothesis that compounds that enter cells can more efficiently deliver their payload of H2S, as opposed to the H2S being delivered only outside the cell. Other less polar slow releasing (<10 μM over 4 days at 5 mM) compounds 4, 11, 15, and 16 have measurable IC50s in most cell lines, supporting the notion that cell penetrating H2S donors are more efficacious. Most likely a combination of extracellular and intracellular release is occurring, and it is the cellular compartment where the compound is targeted that may have the greatest benefit.
    Of the other compounds, methoxy 4 was overall weaker than 1, but generally most compounds have lower IC50s than 1. Despite this, most of these compounds are still only weakly active, with IC50s between 100 and 200 μM. The most potent compounds were found to be phenoxy-benzylamine 14, phenoxy-isopropoxy 16, and bis(thiomorpholine) 20, with IC50values in the range of 50 μM or less in most cases. These compounds come from different H2S release categories (classed as low, medium, and high), highlighting the lack of correlation between in vitro H2S release rate and inhibition of cancer cell proliferation. In addition, it cannot be ruled out that other cellular components, enzymes or small molecules, may play a role in the H2S release mechanism of this compound class.

    Assessment of in Vitro Toxicity

    To assess general toxicity, we also tested compounds in a WI38 normal human lung fibroblast cell line. A therapeutic index (TI) was calculated (ratio of WI38 IC50/cancer cell IC50), which revealed that weakly potent 1 had the widest TI with most of the other compounds in the 2–3-fold range. Compounds 6, 7, 13, and 15 exhibited a TI of over 5, however, as observed for 1, these are generally weakly active compounds. Of the more potent compounds 14, 16, and 20, TIs were in the range of 1.5–3.
    The assessment of toxicity in vitro is constrained by many limitations compared to the more relevant in vivo scenario where compounds are metabolized and distributed, leading to different concentrations in tissues. Hence, in vitro assessments, where cells are bathed in high concentrations of compounds for days, can lead to a high estimation of toxicity. However, we decided to further characterize the toxicity of these compounds by studying them in two other normal cell types, a mouse hepatocyte (TAMH)(78) and a human cardiomyocyte (AC10)(79) derived from liver and heart tissues, respectively. Promising compounds were selected for further evaluation in TAMH and AC10 cells. In general, TAMH cells are more sensitive than AC10 cells to the H2S donors: compound 20 had an IC50 of 120.1 ± 1.5 μM (N = 4) in TAMHs but only inhibited 35.6 ± 1.5% proliferation of the AC10 cells at 100 μM (N = 4). For compound 14, the values were 23.5 ± 1.3 μM (N = 4) and 62.6 ± 2.0 μM (N = 3) for TAMH and AC10 cells, respectively. Compound 16 was also tested in AC10 cardiomyocytes and was found to only inhibit 28.6 ± 1.9% of their proliferation at 100 μM (N = 4), considerably less toxicity than in WI38 cells. Other compounds tested in TAMH cells at 100 μM that did not reach IC50 were 4, 5, 6, 7, 13, and 18. Clearly, toxicity is compound and cell specific. Off-target effects of the compounds could also be contributing to their pharmacology.
    We wanted to further establish this compound series as drug-like and potentially progressable into mouse models of cancer, hence we studied compound 14 in the AMES test for mutagenicity.(80) Strains of Salmonella typhimurium TA98 and TA100 were studied with and without S9 fraction using 2-aminoanthracene as a positive control and 14 at 100 and 10 μg per plate. At both concentrations tested of 14, there were no detectable differences with or without S9, and levels observed were lower than DMSO vehicle controls.

    Physicochemical Property Assessment

    Given that many targeted anticancer agents do not show high TIs in cell viability assays, this data supports further studies of hydrogen sulfide therapy using phosphordithioates as a potential treatment for cancer. Such studies are supported by the reported in vivo efficacy of 1(39) and should include a more complete understanding of cellular and in vivo toxicology. There is no clear trend between in vitro H2S release rate and cancer cell proliferation potency. Benzylamine 14, the most consistently potent compound in the series, releases H2S faster than most of the oxygen linked analogues but much slower than the faster diamino compounds (Tables 2 and 3). In a parallel artificial membrane permeability assay (PAMPA),(81) we discovered that 14 has a permeability of 19 ± 5 nm/s (6 h) and 97 ± 15 nm/s (16 h), which, although still low for a small molecule, is much higher than that of 1 (1.9 ± 0.3 nm/s (6 h), 1.7 ± 0.4 nm/s (16 h)) and other less potent tested compounds 4–7 and 13 (Table 5).
    Table 5. Physicochemical Property Data for Compounds 1 and 4–20
        aqueous solubility (mg/mL, pH 7.4) 
    compdH2S release categoryaMWcLogP (free thiol)b3 h24 hPe (pH 7.4) (10–7 cm/s)
    1medium2893.930.6 ± 0.725.5 ± 0.50.19 ± 0.03 (6 h)

          0.50 ± 0.01 (6 h)

    Intracellular pH Analysis

    When cells are treated with H2S donors with different permeabilities (and different inherent H2S release rates), the H2S levels inside cells could be quite different, which may lead to differences in antiproliferative activity. An alternative indicator for the intracellular levels of H2S, demonstrated for compound 1, is the intracellular pH (pHi) of the cell.(47) A decrease in pHi is attributed to enhanced glycolysis, causing overproduction of metabolic acid lactate and decreased anion and sodium/proton exchanger activity, leading to uncontrolled intracellular acidification and in turn triggering cancer cell death. Treatment of MCF7 cells with both 1 and 14 for 48 h led to significant dose-related effects on pHi (Figure 13).
    At the most discriminating concentration of 50 μM, where there were still enough live cells for analysis, 1 reduced pHi to 7.14 ± 0.07 but 14 reduced pHi to 6.75 ± 0.15. This difference was statistically significant (p < 0.001), with minimal variation between samples taken for each data point (N = 25). This difference in pHi coupled with the increase in permeability at least partly explains the observed 10-fold higher antiproliferative potency of 14 compared to 1 in MCF7 cells. To further characterize the intracellular H2S profile of 1 compared to 14, we next studied these compounds using a new fluorescent probe in cells using confocal microscopy.

    Intracellular H2S Quantification and Imaging

    It is still challenging to reliably and accurately quantify levels of H2S in a complex biological system such as a cell. However, much progress has been made in developing assays which can compare the relative quantity of H2S inside cells. Recently a new probe, 21, was reported which enables specific quantitation of H2S in cells by employing confocal imaging.(60) Thus, it is possible to correlate the intracellular H2S profiles to the observed anticancer potency of H2S donor compounds. Following incubation of MCF7 cells with probe 21 for 3 h, cells were washed and treated with compounds 1 and 14 with readings taken at intervals over 24 h. A standard curve was generated using NaHS (Figure 14A).
    Approximately 4 times the amount of H2S was detected from 14 compared to 1. At 6 h at a concentration of 200 μM, 14 released 41.5 ± 0.3 μM, whereas 1 released only 5.41 ± 0.2 μM (Figure 14B). These levels are after only 6 h of incubation but, for 14, are already significantly higher than the amounts of H2S quantified in aqueous acetonitrile at the same concentration (Figure 15: 9.03 ± 0.57 μM for 14 and 6.72 ± 0.41 μM for 1 at 200 μM). At 400 μM (6 h time point), 14 released 48.2 ± 1.1 μM, whereas 1 released only 9.56 ± 0.6 μM, underlining the increased H2S in the cell with 14. At the 24 h time point, 1 had increased to 16.1 ± 1.1 μM at 200 μM and 31.4 ± 0.9 μM at 400 μM. However, although 14 had increased to 93.4 ± 1.9 μM at 200 μM, less H2S was measured at the higher concentration of 400 μM (74.6 ± 0.8 μM), albeit 50% higher than at 200 μM (Figure 14C). Given that the aqueous solubility of 14 is 180 μg/mL (24 h incubation), substantially less than 1 (25.5 mg/mL), it is not surprising to see nonlinear effects with 14 above this concentration. Moreover, the data could be confounded by changes in the cell, particularly initiation of cell death pathways, at this very high concentration of 14, over 10-fold higher than its proliferation IC50.
    When MCF7 cells are treated with the higher concentration of 1 (Figure 14D(e)) and 14 (Figure 14D(f)), significantly more H2S was detected in the 14-treated cells via confocal microscopy. The levels of H2S appeared quite similar between the 100 μM NaHS control and the 14-treated cells assuming good penetration of NaHS-derived H2S into cells. Although 1 and 14 have a similar in vitro H2S releasing profile in aqueous acetonitrile, the good permeability of 14 appears to be responsible for its improved anticancer cellular activity by delivering more H2S into cells.

    Design and Synthesis of More Potent Compounds

    Having established that more potent antiproliferative H2S releasing compounds with promising drug-like properties can indeed be found, as compared to 1, we became encouraged to target increased potency by further, more extensive, modification of the structure of the donor compounds. Our wider studies to explore structural analogues of the phosphordithioates led us to consider monothio derivatives. This can be done with either a simple substitution of one sulfur for a carbon or other heteroatom or by cyclizing the structure. Cyclization may provide more control over the reactivity of the donors due to limited conformational freedom of the ligands attached to the reactive phosphorus. Hence we prepared a series of five-membered 2,3-dihydro-2-phenyl-2-sulfanylenebenzo[d][1,3,2]oxazaphospholes, where the phosphorus was locked in a five-membered ring and substituted with a nitrogen and oxygen (Scheme 1 and Table 6).
    Table 6. Compounds 22–30 with Yields and 31P NMR Chemical Shift
    compdR1R2R3R4H2S release categoryayield (%)31P NMR δ (ppm, CDCl3)
    22HHHHhigh3093.87
    23HHMeHmedium61.597.72
    24HHHOMemedium11.394.34
    25HHMeOMelow10.398.04
    26MeHHOMemedium3494.99
    27MeHHOPhmedium25.194.15
    28HOMeHOMelow1095.30
    29HFHOMemedium42.496.30
    30HFHOPhlow4995.52
    a

    See Figure 16.

    Compounds 24 to 30 were prepared by direct reaction of the appropriate aminophenol with LR under reflux conditions. In general, reactions proceeded smoothly and products were stable enough to be quickly purified by flash column chromatography. This increased stability versus the phosphordithioates was a distinct advantage. Para-phenyl analogues 22 and 23 were prepared under milder conditions from benzenephosphonothioyl dichloride in DCM at 0 °C. Yields were generally low and products were more stable as solids than the phosphordithioates, supporting our original hypothesis that cyclization would stabilize the reactivity of the compounds.
    In these structures the phosphorus atom bears four different substituents and is unusual in that each substituent is a different atom. Hence these are chiral phosphorus compounds, however we made no attempt to separate the enantiomers.

    Quantification of Evolved H2S in Vitro and Rate of Release

    We were concerned that the greater stability of the cyclized compounds could also lead to less reactivity as an H2S donor. Ideally, an H2S donor should be stable until activated in the biological system being targetted. Fortunately, following H2S quantification with probe 2, a good range of H2S release profiles were obtained for this first group of cyclized compounds. Compounds were tested at 1 mM concentration to be able to detect H2S evolved from the weakest donors and compare directly to all compounds in the series (Figure 16). Unsubstituted compound 22 had the highest release of the series (150 μM over 3 days at 22 °C at 1 mM and at 37 °C 77.6 μM evolved at 100 μM representing 77.6% of available sulfur). All other explored derivatives evolved less H2S than 22 under either condition: N-methylation (23) was 3.5–5-fold lower, possibly due to conformational effects influencing the phenyl ring; an electron donating methoxy group (24) was 2–3-fold lower (a slightly stronger effect than the difference between 12 and 14 where the difference is less than 2-fold). Combination of the latter two modifications, to give 25, significantly reduced evolution of H2S from this scaffold. Similar to 12 and 14, methoxy 26 and phenoxy 27 release H2S at concentrations within 2-fold of each other. Electron donating methoxy groups at R2 and R4 abolished H2S evolution to undetectable levels using probe 2. Introduction of a fluoro group at R2 (29) did little to change the release rate (compare with 24), however, fluoro-phenoxy (30) suffered a 10-fold reduction over its methoxy counterpart 29. Although the highest releaser 22 has the lowest 31P chemical shift, there was no apparent general trend of H2S release within the narrow 31P chemical shift range of these compounds, suggesting that multiple conflicting effects are responsible for the observed reactivity of individual compounds. Similar to the phophordithioate series, the cyclic series are significantly more reactive at physiological temperature hence cellular studies are highly relevant.

    Mechanism of in Vitro H2S Release

    We studied the mechanism of release of H2S from 1, 22, and 24 by analyzing the products produced from the reaction. We propose a water hydrolysis mechanism for both series of compounds (Supporting Information Figure S89). This is supported by the isolation of a methanol addition product when 24 is dissolved in methanol (Supporting Information Scheme S2, NMR and mass spectra are given in Supporting Information Figures S90–S92). Furthermore, the product from the complete hydrolysis of 22 in aqueous DMSO is phenylphosphonic acid, which exhibits an identical 31P NMR signal to the commercial phenylphosphonic acid reference material.

    Biological Evaluation in Living Cells

    In cells, the strongest releaser, 22, was also the most potent compound from all compounds studied herein with IC50s of 5.7 and 6.12 μM against proliferating MCF7 and SKOV3 cells, respectively (Table 7). All other compounds from the series were less potent. However, all compounds did have positive therapeutic windows when the ratio of their WI38 IC50s to cancer cell proliferation IC50s were compared. With a therapeutic window of over 8-fold, compound 22 was not only the most potent but also the safest compound from all thiophosphorus compounds studied thus far. No direct correlation between efficacy and in vitro H2S release was apparent. Given the complexities of H2S release in cells (extra- versus intracellular), this is not surprising. However, it does suggest that release should be studied inside cells to confirm that the in vitro effects are transferable. Hence, the most promising compound, 22, was compared directly with 1 and 14 by using probe 21 in MCF7 cells (Figure 17). Absolute values of 1 and 14 were within 2-fold of the first experiment when compared at the same time point (see Figure 14). All compounds were tested at the same high concentration (400 μM) to ensure enough signal over the short incubation time, optimized to ensure cells were still alive when harvested. Compound 22 released the highest intracellular amounts of H2S followed by 14 then 1. This data correlates with the observed antiproliferative potency of these compounds.
    Table 7. IC50 (μM) for Cell Proliferation Inhibition of Compounds in Different Cancer Cell Lines and One Normal Cell Line
    compdH2S release categoryaMCF7 IC50 (μM)SKOV3 IC50 (μM)WI38 IC50 (μM)therapeutic indexb
    22high5.7 ± 0.26.12 ± 0.2>50>8.2–8.8
    23medium72.7 ± 1.869.4 ± 0.9206.7 ± 0.42.8–3.0
    24medium37.1 ± 0.538.1 ± 1.794.4 ± 6.42.5
    25low42.6 ± 1.344.2 ± 1.092.5 ± 0.52.1–2.2
    26medium93.2 ± 2.1211.0 ± 1.3>400>1.9–4.3
    27medium185.6 ± 10.0196.2 ± 2.0>400>2.0–2.2
    28low39.4 ± 1.430.2 ± 1.7115.2 ± 0.82.9–3.8
    29medium33.6 ± 0.270.8 ± 1.9>2002.8–6.0
    30low13.6 ± 0.638.1 ± 1.865.6 ± 3.31.7–4.8
    a

    See Figure 16.

    b

    WI38/most and least sensitive cell lines.

    Further Assessment of In Vitro Toxicity

    To further explore the surprisingly high therapeutic window in WI38s, we studied both 1 and 22 in MCF7 cells and in nontransformed mammary epithelial cells, MCF10A, as well as the hepatocyte TAMH(78) and the cardiomyocyte AC10,(79) representative normal cell lines of the liver and heart, respectively. In MCF7 cells, studied in 48-well plates at higher cell density, 22 was clearly significantly more potent than 1 when tested at similar concentrations (Figure 18). There was a clearly higher sensitivity for MCF7s versus MCF10As for 1 up to its top concentration of 500 μM. Similarly for 22 at lower concentrations (15.3 and 31.3 μM), MCF7 cells were more sensitive than their normal counterpart. However, at higher concentrations, 22 did not show any significant preference. In TAMH hepatocytes, 22 had a cell proliferation IC50 of 26.3 ± 0.9 μM, and in AC10 cardiomyocytes, the IC50 value was 98 ± 11 μM, considerably higher values than in cancer cells under similar conditions.

    Further Assessments of Cellular Activity and Mechanism of Action

    Assessment of Cellular Activity in Solid Tumor Spheroids

    Tumor spheroids are a more physiologically relevant assay than monolayer cultures and more accurately reflect the complexity of an in vivo solid tumor.(82) To further characterize the anticancer activity of the strong H2S releaser, 22, compared to the weak H2S releaser, 1, we tested them in MCF7 tumor spheroids side-by-side in the same ultralow attachment plate over a 14 day growth period (Figure 19). At the high concentrations where 1 is partially effective (spheroids treated with 400 μM 1 were 917 ± 80 μm in size after 14 days representing a 350% growth (3.5-fold), 800 μM treatment of 1 resulted in an average spheroid diameter of 592 ± 59 μm (250% growth), compared to day zero size of 261 ± 11 μm and 238 ± 29 μm, respectively), 22 almost completely inhibits tumor spheroid growth (spheroids treated with 400 μM 22 were 361 ± 38 μm in size after 14 days representing a 165% growth, 800 μM treatment of 22 resulted in an average spheroid diameter of 315 ± 28 μm (133% growth), compared to day zero size of 218 ± 29 μm and 237 ± 12 μm, respectively). This data can be most clearly visualized when comparing microscopy photographs of individual spheroids (Figure 19B). At the lower concentration of 100 μM, 22 resulted in a spheroid growth of 210% (2.1 fold), corresponding to a spheroid size of 503 ± 26 μm after 14 days. Note that the untreated controls grew to a size of 1113 ± 27 μm (461% growth over original size). Hence, even at the lower concentration tested 22 inhibits spheroid growth by nearly 70% (see Figure 19A).

    Assessment of Mechanism of Cell Death

    Poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) has been implicated in cell death pathways either via apoptosis or necrosis.(83, 84) During apoptosis (programmed cell death) PARP is cleaved by caspases to give a N-terminal DNA binding domain. Caspases, specifically caspases 3, 7, and 9, are cysteine proteases which cleave numerous specific cellular proteins during apoptosis.(85, 86) Increase in cleaved PARP and activated caspases upon drug treatment indicates cell death via apoptosis. Treatment of MCF7 cells with compounds 1 and 22 gave dose related increases in cleaved PARP and activated caspase-7, indicating that the H2S releasing compounds triggered cell death by apoptosis (Figure 20).

    Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In conclusion, two series of slow H2S releasing compounds, derived from 1, based on phosphordithioate and cyclic phosphorane structures, have been developed and evaluated. In vitro H2S assay analysis, adapted from the literature using probe 2, demonstrated the capabilities of these compounds as slow, medium, and fast H2S releasers. Compared to 1, improved inhibition of solid tumor cell proliferation was observed when these compounds were evaluated in MCF7, MBA-MD231, SKOV3, and PC3 cell lines. A preferred phosphordithioate, 14, reduced pHi more significantly than 1 and also produced more H2S in cells, which can be explained by the higher permeability of 14. Although compound 14 did not show a significant therapeutic window in three different normal cell lines, it was also not more toxic in those cells and was negative in the AMES test. Further development of these compounds by cyclization led to the more potent phosphorane 22 (FW1256) with a single-digit micromolar cellular potency and good therapeutic window of greater than 8-fold over WI38 cells. A good therapeutic window was also seen with cardiomyocytes and a lower window in hepatocytes and MCF10A cells. The more physiologically relevant tumor spheroid assay demonstrates the superior potency of 22 over 1. Further, apoptosis was shown to be the mechanism of cell death of compound 22. Taken together, this work provides a “toolbox” of compounds with useful wide ranging H2S release rates, a logical series of assays to evaluate such compounds, and a preferred compound, 22, which is now being further studied as a promising cancer therapeutic. H2S therapy is in its infancy, but with judicious synthesis, selection, and evaluation of new drug-like H2S releasing compounds, it should be possible to eventually study H2S releasers as potential new clinical cancer therapies.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    General Procedures and Methods

    Experiments involving moisture and/or air sensitive components were performed under a positive pressure of nitrogen in oven-dried glassware equipped with a rubber septum inlet. Dried solvents and liquid reagents were transferred by oven-dried syringes or hypodermic syringe cooled to ambient temperature in a desiccator. Reaction mixtures were stirred in 50 mL round-bottomed flasks (rbf) with Teflon-coated magnetic stirring bars unless otherwise stated. Solvents were removed in vacuo using either a Heidolph or Büchi rotary evaporator equipped with a condenser cooled to 0 °C.

    Instrumentation

    Proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) and carbon NMR (13C NMR) spectra were recorded in DMSO-d6 unless otherwise stated. 1H (400 MHz) and 13C (101 MHz) with complete proton decoupling were performed on a 400 MHz Bruker Ultra Shield NMR spectrometer. Chemical shifts were reported as δ in units of parts per million (ppm) downfield from tetramethylsilane (δ 0.00), using the residual solvent signal as an internal standard: DMSO (1H NMR, δ 2.50 multiplet; 13C NMR, δ 39.5, multiplet), CDCl3 (1H NMR, δ 7.26 singlet; 13C NMR, δ 77.0 triplet). Multiplicities were given as s (singlet), d (doublet), t (triplet), q (quartet), quintet, m (multiplet), dd (doublet of doublets), ddd (doublet of doublet of doublets), dt (doublet of triplets), dq (doublet of quartets), dm (doublet of multiplets), and br (broad). Coupling constants (J) were recorded in hertz (Hz). The number of proton atoms (n) for a given resonance was indicated by nH. The number of carbon atoms (n) for a given resonance was indicated by nC. High resolution electrospray ionization (ESI) mass spectra were obtained on a Shimadzu MS-IT-TOF spectrometer. Shimadzu Formula Predictor software was used to process the data. MS and HRMS were reported in units of mass to charge ratio (m/z). Mass samples were dissolved in CH3CN/DMSO mixture (HPLC grade, 90% CH3CN). Unless otherwise noted, purity of the final compounds was verified by reverse phase high pressure liquid chromatography (HPLC) on a Shimadzu SPD-20A HPLC system. The test compound was dissolved in MeCN and injected through a 100 μL loop at a flow rate of 0.7 mL/min, with UV detection at 254 and 230 nm. Separation was carried out on a Zorbax SB-C18 column (250 mm × 4.6 mm, 5 μm, Agilent) using mobile phase of MeCN (95%)/water (5%)/0.1% trifluoroacetic acid (TFA). The separation on the column was followed for 15 min for the detection of the peak corresponding to the test compound. Purity of each compound was assessed from the area of the major peak compared to total area of peaks obtained on the chromatogram. All compounds were >95% pure.

    Materials

    All commercial reagents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, Fluka, Alfa Aesar, Merck, TCI, or Acros and were of the highest purity grade available. They were used without further purification unless specified. All reaction solvents used, such as dichloromethane or toluene, were freshly collected from a solvent purification system. All compounds synthesized were stored in a −20 °C freezer. Some of the described compounds have been made previously but not as morpholine or benzylamine salts.(87)

    General and Representative Procedures

    General Procedure for the Preparation of GYY4137 (1)

    Compound 1 was prepared following the reported procedure:(37, 88) Lawesson’s Reagent (LR) (50 g, 0.125 mol) was suspended in anhydrous dichloromethane (625 mL) under N2, and the suspension was then cooled to 0 °C. Morpholine (48.1 g, 0.55 mol) was added slowly to the suspension at 0 °C. The mixture was then warmed to RT and stirred for about 2 h. The product slowly precipitated from the reaction mixture, forming an ionic salt. This salt was filtered and washed with dichloromethane (600 mL, twice) to good purity. The solid was dried under vacuum at room temperature, avoiding heat to give 62 g (67%) of 1. GYY4137 (1) is highly water soluble, and care must be taken to avoid any aqueous workup or washing with polar solvents. 1H, 13C, and 31P NMR confirmed the identity of 1. 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O) δ 8.02–7.84 (m, 2H), 7.05–6.94 (m, 2H), 3.93–3.84 (m, 4H), 3.81 (s, 3H), 3.71–3.54 (m, 4H), 3.23–3.21 (m, 4H), 2.86 (dd, J = 9.6, 5.5 Hz, 4H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, D2O) δ 161.03 (d, J(C–P) = 3.0 Hz), 132.48 (d, J(C–P) = 12.8 Hz), 131.42 (d, J(C–P) = 110.1 Hz), 113.56 (d, J(C–P) = 14.6 Hz), 66.66 (d, J(C–P) = 11.7 Hz), 63.64, 55.49, 44.72 (d, J(C–P) = 1.8 Hz), 43.19. 31P NMR (162 MHz, D2O) δ 89.00 (s).

    Representative Procedure for the Preparation of 4, 5, 6, 7, 10, 11, 15, and 16

    Lawesson’s Reagent (1 mmol, for 4, 5, 6, 7, 10, and 11) or Belleau’s reagent (1 mmol, for 15 and 16) was added to a 50 mL dry round-bottomed flask with a magnetic stirring bar under N2 at room temperature. Then 5 mL of anhydrous toluene was added, followed by addition of 2 mmol of the nucleophile (alcohol or phenol). The mixture was heated to 80 °C until a clear solution formed. Then the mixture was cooled to room temperature, and 2 mmol of morpholine was added. The mixture was then left still for the product to precipitate. The solid product was filtered off, washed, and dried under high vacuum.

    Representative Procedure for the Preparation of 8 and 9

    Lawesson’s Reagent (1 mmol) was added to a 50 mL dry round-bottomed flask with a magnetic stirring bar under N2 at room temperature. Then 5 mL anhydrous dichloromethane was added. Following this, the appropriate amino alcohol (2.2 mmol) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 3 h. During this period, a white solid precipitated. The solid product was filtered, washed, and dried under high vacuum.

    Representative Procedure for the Preparation of 12, 13, and 14

    Lawesson’s Reagent (1 mmol, for 12) or Belleau’s reagent (1 mmol, for 13 and 14) was added to a 50 mL dry round-bottomed flask with a magnetic stirring bar under N2 at room temperature. Then 3 mL of anhydrous dichloromethane was added. Following this, morpholine (for 13, 4.4 mmol) or benzyl amine (for 12and 14, 4.4 mmol) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 3 h. During this period, the reaction mixture became clear and then a white solid precipitated. If no precipitate came out, hexane was added until turbid, and the mixture was left still to allow product precipitation. The solid product was filtered, washed, and dried under high vacuum.

    Representative Procedure for the Preparation of 17, 18, 19, and 20

    Phosphorus pentasulfide (P4S10) (1 mmol) was added to a 50 mL dry round-bottomed flask with a magnetic stirring bar under N2 at room temperature. Then 3 mL of anhydrous dichloromethane was added. Following this, the specific amine (12 mmol) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 3–24 h until solid product had precipitated. The solid product was filtered, washed, and dried under high vacuum.
    Note: the following nucleophiles did not yield a precipitate in our hands: anilines, pyrazole, and thiophenols. Carbon nucleophiles also did not give desired products.

    Representative Procedure for the Preparation of 2,3-Dihydro-2-phenyl-2-sulfanylenebenzo[d][1,3,2]oxazaphospholes

    For 22 and 23: aminophenol (2 mmol) and triethylamine (4 mmol) were mixed in dry DCM under nitrogen. The mixture was cooled to 0 °C, and then thiophenylphosphonic acid dichloride (2 mmol) was added. The mixture was slowly warmed to room temperature and stirred for 2 h. The product was purified via flash chromatography and dried under high vacuum.
    For 24, 25, 26, 27, 28, 29, and 30
    Aminophenol (4 mmol) and Lawsson’s Reagent (2 mmol) or Belleau’s reagent (2 mmol) were mixed in dry toluene (10 mL) under nitrogen. The mixture was heated to reflux and stirred under reflux until a clear solution formed (up to about 3 h). The mixture was loaded directly onto a silica gel column, and the product was purified via flash chromatography and dried under high vacuum.

    Data for Specific Compounds (Using the Appropriate Representative Procedure)

    4-Methoxyphenyl(methoxy)phosphonodithioate Morpholine Salt (4)
