LRMS (ESI) m/z 307.3 (M – H+), HRMS (ESI) m/z 307.0491 ([M – H+]), calcd for [C14H17N2PS2 – H+] 307.0498 (Δ = 2.3 ppm). Degrades too quickly for HPLC analysis.
    Bis(thiomorpholine)phosphonodithioate (20)
    White solid, yield: 36.3%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 6.62 (br, 2H), 3.10–2.88 (m, 12H), 2.68–2.54 (m, 12H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 46.43, 26.12. 31P NMR (162 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 0.74. HRMS (ESI) m/z 298.9947 ([M – H+]), calcd for [C8H17N2PS2 – H+] 298.9939 (Δ = 2.7 ppm). Degrades too quickly for HPLC analysis.
    2-Phenyl-2,3-dihydrobenzo[d][1,3,2]oxazaphosphole 2-sulfide (22)
    White solid, yield: 30%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.99–7.88 (m, 2H), 7.59–7.55 (m, 1H), 7.49–7.41 (m, 2H), 7.03 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 6.97 (t, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 6.88 (t, J = 2.0 Hz, 2H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 146.12 (s), 134.24 (d, J = 139.4 Hz), 133.74 (d, J = 7.1 Hz), 133.15 (d, J = 3.1 Hz), 131.19 (d, J = 13.3 Hz), 128.50 (d, J = 15.8 Hz), 123.35 (s), 121.29 (s), 112.51 (d, J = 9.0 Hz), 111.43 (d, J = 11.0 Hz). 31P NMR (162 MHz, CDCl3) δ 93.87. LRMS (ESI) m/z 247.9 (M + H+).
    3-Methyl-2-phenyl-2,3-dihydrobenzo[d][1,3,2]oxazaphosphole 2-Sulfide (23)
    White solid, yield: 61.5%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.92–7.78 (m, 2H), 7.64–7.52 (m, 1H), 7.46 (ddd, J = 7.4, 4.4, 1.5 Hz, 2H), 7.04 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 2H), 6.92–6.81 (m, 1H), 6.76–6.68 (m, 1H), 3.01 (d, J = 11.3 Hz, 3H). 31P NMR (162 MHz, CDCl3) δ 97.72 (s). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 145.88 (d, J = 3.1 Hz), 136.62 (d, J = 13.1 Hz), 133.16 (d, J = 3.4 Hz), 133.1 (s, d, J = 134.33 Hz), 131.24 (d, J = 13.2 Hz), 128.57 (d, J = 15.3 Hz), 123.36 (s), 119.94 (s), 111.90 (d, J = 8.2 Hz), 108.41 (d, J = 8.7 Hz), 27.58 (d, J = 6.0 Hz). LRMS (ESI) m/z 262.2 (M + H+).
    2-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-2,3-dihydrobenzo[d][1,3,2]oxazaphosphole 2-Sulfide (24)
    White solid, yield: 11.3%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.88–7.82 (m, 2H), 6.99 (d, J = 4.0 Hz, 1H), 6.96–6.89 (m, 3H), 6.88–6.82 (m, 2H), 5.47 (d, J = 16.0 Hz, 1H), 3.84 (s, 3H). 31P NMR (162 MHz, CDCl3) δ 94.34. 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 163.54 (d, J = 3.1 Hz), 145.81 (d, J = 2.1 Hz), 133.72 (d, J = 7.1 Hz), 133.55 (d, J = 15.15 Hz), 125.35 (d, J = 152.3 Hz), 123.16 (s), 120.92 (s), 113.82 (d, J = 17.0 Hz), 112.27 (d, J = 9.1 Hz), 111.25 (d, J = 11.0 Hz), 55.45 (s). LRMS (ESI) m/z 278.1 (M + H+).
    2-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-3-methyl-2,3-dihydrobenzo[d][1,3,2]oxazaphosphole 2-Sulfide (25)
    White solid, yield: 10.3%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.79 (dd, J = 14.8, 8.9 Hz, 2H), 7.02 (d, J = 7.7 Hz, 2H), 6.94 (dd, J = 8.9, 3.4 Hz, 2H), 6.84 (s, 1H), 6.71 (d, J = 7.4 Hz, 1H), 3.85 (s, 3H), 2.98 (d, J = 11.3 Hz, 3H). 31P NMR (162 MHz, CDCl3) δ 98.04 (s). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 163.70 (s), 145.81 (s), 136.61 (s), 133.77 (d, J = 14.9 Hz), 124.29 (d, J = 142.4 Hz), 123.24 (s), 119.80 (s), 114.01 (d, J = 16.7 Hz), 111.90 (d, J = 8.3 Hz), 108.28 (d, J = 8.8 Hz), 55.50 (s), 29.69 (s). LRMS (ESI) m/z 314.4 (M + Na+).
    2-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-6-methyl-2,3-dihydrobenzo[d][1,3,2]oxazaphosphole 2-Sulfide (26)
    White solid, yield: 34%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.97–7.84 (m, 2H), 6.95–6.92 (m, 2H), 6.85 (s, 1H), 6.77–6.72 (m, 2H), 4.93 (br s, 1H), 3.85 (s, 3H), 2.30 (s, 3H). 31P NMR (162 MHz, CDCl3) δ 94.99. 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 163.56 (d, J = 3.1 Hz), 146.05 (s), 133.55 (d, J = 15.1 Hz), 131.23 (d, J = 7.1 Hz), 131.11 (s), 125.65 (d, J = 146.5 Hz), 123.31 (s), 113.83 (d, J = 17.0 Hz), 113.19 (d, J = 8.8 Hz), 110.96 (d, J = 11.0 Hz), 55.48 (s), 21.12 (s). LRMS (ESI) m/z 292.1 (M + H+).
    6-Methyl-2-(4-phenoxyphenyl)-2,3-dihydrobenzo[d][1,3,2]oxazaphosphole 2-Sulfide (27)
    White solid, yield: 25.1%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.94–7.78 (m, 2H), 7.45–7.31 (m, 2H), 7.24–7.14 (m, 1H), 7.06–7.04 (m, 2H), 7.01–6.94 (m, 2H), 6.84 (s, 1H), 6.74 (t, J = 2.0 Hz, 2 H), 5.25 (br s, 1H), 2.30 (s, 3H). 31P NMR (162 MHz, CDCl3) δ 94.15. 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 162.05 (d, J = 3.3 Hz), 155.23 (s), 146.00 (d, J = 2.0 Hz), 133.47 (d, J = 15.0 Hz), 131.13 (t, J = 3.4 Hz), 130.04 (s), 127.8 (d, J = 144.4 Hz), 124.72 (s), 123.38 (s), 120.14 (s), 117.25 (d, J = 16.9 Hz), 113.12 (d, J = 9.0 Hz), 111.06 (d, J = 10.9 Hz), 21.09 (s). LRMS (ESI) m/z 354.1 (M + H+).
    5-Methoxy-2-(4-methoxyphenyl)-2,3-dihydrobenzo[d][1,3,2]oxazaphosphole 2-Sulfide (28)
    White solid, yield: 10%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.00–7.76 (m, 2H), 6.95–6.90 (m, 3H), 6.53–6.41 (m, 1H), 6.36 (dd, J = 8.7, 2.7 Hz, 1H), 5.19 (br s, 1H), 3.85 (s, 3H), 3.77 (s, 3H). 31P NMR (162 MHz, CDCl3) δ 95.30. 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 163.64 (s), 155.94 (s), 140.22 (s), 134.53 (d, J = 8.1 Hz), 133.59 (d, J = 15.3 Hz), 125.51 (d, J = 145.4 Hz), 113.86 (d, J = 17.1 Hz), 112.27 (d, J = 8.4 Hz), 104.51 (s), 98.98 (d, J = 11.1 Hz), 55.85 (s), 55.50 (s). LRMS (ESI) m/z 308.3 (M + H+).
    5-Fluoro-2-(4-methoxyphenyl)-2,3-dihydrobenzo[d][1,3,2]oxazaphosphole 2-Sulfide (29)
    White solid, yield: 42.4%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.02–7.74 (m, 2H), 7.01–6.86 (m, 3H), 6.63–6.47 (m, 2H), 5.52 (d, J = 17.0 Hz, 1H), 3.86 (s, 3H). 31P NMR (162 MHz, CDCl3) δ 96.30 (s). 19F NMR (376 MHz, CDCl3) δ −118.50 (s). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 163.82 (d, J = 3.4 Hz), 159.91 (s), 157.51 (s), 141.90 (s), 134.63 (dd, J = 12.4, 7.7 Hz), 133.70 (d, J = 15.3 Hz), 124.99 (d, J = 145.4 Hz), 113.98 (d, J = 17.3 Hz), 112.45 (t, J = 9.1), 106.49 (d, J = 24.2 Hz), 99.62 (dd, J = 28.9, 11.1 Hz), 55.55 (s). LRMS (ESI) m/z 296.3 (M + H+).
    5-Fluoro-2-(4-phenoxyphenyl)-2,3-dihydrobenzo[d][1,3,2]oxazaphosphole 2-Sulfide (30)
    White solid, yield: 49%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.85–7.67 (m, 2H), 7.34–7.24 (m, 2H), 7.19–7.01 (m, 3H), 6.95 (ddd, J = 4.2, 3.2, 1.7 Hz, 2H), 6.92–6.86 (m, 2H), 6.80 (dd, J = 8.4, 4.7 Hz, 1H), 6.54–6.20 (m, 2H), 5.55 (d, J = 18.3 Hz, 1H). 31P NMR (162 MHz, CDCl3) δ 95.52 (s). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 162.45 (d, J = 3.3 Hz), 159.94 (s), 157.54 (s), 155.14 (s), 141.91 (t, J = 2.2 Hz), 137.91 (s), 134.60 (dd, J = 12.3, 7.6 Hz), 133.69 (d, J = 15.2 Hz), 130.17 (s), 129.09 (s), 128.28 (s), 127.13 (d, J = 143.4 Hz), 125.35 (s), 124.94 (s), 120.31 (s), 117.32 (d, J = 17.1 Hz), 112.46 (t, J = 9.1 Hz), 106.59 (d, J = 24.2 Hz), 99.74 (dd, J = 29.1, 11.2 Hz). LRMS (ESI) m/z 358.3 (M + H+).

    Quantitative Detection of H2S in Vitro

    General Experimental

    Fluorescence measurements using probe compound 2 were obtained on a Tecan microplate reader (model Infinite M200) set at gain 80 with excitation wavelength 325 nm and emission wavelength 450 nm. Buffer used was pH 7.4 phosphate buffered saline (European Pharmacopoeia reagent purchased from Scientific Resources, Singapore). Sodium sulfide was purchased as a nonahydrate from Sigma Aldrich and stored in a desiccator.
    Probe (Compound 2) Calibration (200 μM)
    A 400 μM stock solution of 2 in buffer solution (“buffer solution” = acetonitrile:pH 7.4 buffer; 9:1 volume ratio) was dispensed into 15 4-mL screw-cap glass vials (1.5 mL stock solution per vial). A 400 μM solution of sodium sulfide (Na2S) in buffer solution was added to the probe solution and the total volume made up to 3 mL with buffer solution so that the final probe concentration was 200 μM, and the final Na2S concentrations are 0, 50, 100, 150, and 200 μM. Hence, for each Na2S concentration, there are three sample vials (N = 3). The samples were kept at 22–24 °C in the dark (the probe is light sensitive). Fluorescence readings (gain = 80) were recorded for three samples from each vial.
    Probe Calibration (1.0 mM)
    A 2 mM stock solution of 2 in buffer solution (“buffer solution” = acetonitrile:pH 7.4 buffer; 9:1 volume ratio) was dispensed into 18 4-mL screw-cap glass vials (1.5 mL stock solution per vial). A 2 mM solution of sodium sulfide (Na2S) in buffer solution was added to the probe solution and the total volume made up to 3 mL with buffer solution so that the final probe concentration was 1 mM, and the final Na2S concentrations are 0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1.0 mM. Hence for each Na2S concentration, there are three sample vials (N = 3). The samples were kept at 22–24 °C in the dark (the probe is light sensitive). Fluorescence readings (gain = 80) were recorded for three samples from each vial.
    H2S Release of 1 at 0.2 mM (22 °C)
    A stock solution of 2 mM probe in buffer solution (“buffer solution” = acetonitrile:pH 7.4 buffer; 9:1 volume ratio) was dispensed into three 4-mL screw-cap glass vials (0.2 mL stock solution per vial). To each of these vials was added 1.76 mL of buffer solution. A stock solution of 10 mM 1 in buffer solution was added to each of these three vials (40 μL per vial). The total volume of 2 mL gives a final probe concentration of 0.2 mM and concentration of 1 was 0.2 mM. The samples were kept at 22–24 °C in the dark. Fluorescence readings (gain = 80) were recorded for three samples from each vial per day for the duration of the experiment.
    H2S Release of 1 at 1.0 mM (22 °C)
    A stock solution of 2 mM probe in buffer solution (“buffer solution” = acetonitrile:pH 7.4 buffer; 9:1 volume ratio) was dispensed into three 4-mL screw-cap glass vials (0.2 mL stock solution per vial). To each of these vials was added 1.6 mL of buffer solution. A stock solution of 10 mM 1 in buffer solution was added to each of these three vials (0.2 mL per vial). The total volume of 2 mL gave a final probe concentration of 0.2 mM and concentration of 1 was 1 mM. The samples were kept at 22–24 °C in the dark. Fluorescence readings (gain = 80) were recorded for three samples from each vial per day for the duration of the experiment.
    H2S Release of 1 at 5 mM (22 °C)
    A stock solution of 2 mM probe in buffer solution (“buffer solution” = acetonitrile:pH 7.4 buffer; 9:1 volume ratio) was dispensed into three 4-mL screw-cap glass vials (0.2 mL stock solution per vial). To each of these vials was added 0.8 mL of buffer solution. A stock solution of 10 mM 1 in buffer solution was added to each of these three vials (1 mL per vial). The total volume of 2 mL gave a final probe concentration of 0.2 mM and concentration of 1 was 5 mM. The samples were kept at 22–24 °C in the dark. Fluorescence readings (gain = 80) were recorded for three samples from each vial per day for the duration of the experiment.
    H2S Release of 1 at 37 °C
    The same procedure as room temperature was applied to 1 (at concentrations of 0.2 and 1 mM) for H2S release at 37 °C, with samples incubated at 37 °C for the duration of the experiment.
    H2S Release of 1 at 5 mM (37 °C)
    A stock solution of 2 mM probe in buffer solution (“buffer solution” = acetonitrile:pH 7.4 buffer; 9:1 volume ratio) was dispensed into three 4-mL screw-cap glass vials (1 mL stock solution per vial). A stock solution of 10 mM 1 in buffer solution was added to each of these three vials (1 mL per vial). The total volume of 2 mL gave a final probe concentration of 1.0 mM and concentration of 1 was 5 mM. The samples were kept at 37 °C in the dark. Fluorescence readings (gain = 80) were recorded for three samples from each vial per day for the duration of the experiment.

    Representative Procedure for the Quantitative Detection of H2S in Vitro for New Compounds

    Procedure Using 0.2 mM of Probe 2
    To each of three 4-mL screw-cap glass vials was added 0.01 mmol of the test compound. A stock solution of 0.2 mM probe in buffer solution (“buffer solution” = acetonitrile:pH 7.4 buffer; 9:1 volume ratio) was dispensed into these three vials (2 mL stock solution per vial). A clear solution was obtained. The samples were kept at 22–24 or 37 °C in the dark. Fluorescence readings (gain = 80) were recorded for three samples from each vial per day for the duration of the experiment.
    Procedure Using 1.0 mM of Probe 2
    To each of three 4-mL screw-cap glass vials was added 0.001 or 0.01 mmol of the test compound. A stock solution of 1 mM probe in buffer solution (“buffer solution” = acetonitrile:pH 7.4 buffer; 9:1 volume ratio) was dispensed into these three vials (2 mL stock solution per vial). A clear solution was obtained. The samples were kept at 37 °C in the dark. Fluorescence readings (gain = 80) were recorded for three samples from each vial per day for the duration of the experiment.

    General Procedure for H2S Detection with Headspace GC-MS (HS-GC-MS)

    GCMS Machine Parameters
    Column, DB-1 capillary 30 m × 320 μm × 0.25 μm; oven, start at 40 °C, hold for 5 min, then raise temp at 5 °C/min to 75 °C and hold for 20 min (total run time 32 min); carrier gas, He at 17.5 psi, 1.5 mL/min with an average velocity of 22 cm/s; injection mode, splitless. MSD = 33–100 amu. First, 50 mg of 1 was suspended in 3 mL of pH 7.4 phosphate buffered saline in a 6 mL microwave tube. The tube was sealed and then evacuated under vacuum via syringe needle. The cap of the microwave tube was sealed again with parafilm to obtain a gas-tight seal. After heating at 100 °C for 12 h, 1 mL of the headspace gas was withdrawn and injected into the GCMS machine with a Hamilton 1 mL gas-tight syringe. All injections were done manually.

    Determination of Cell Proliferation Inhibition by the Crystal Violet Assay

    MCF7 human breast cancer, SKOV3 human epithelial ovarian cancer, and WI38 human diploid lung fibroblasts were grown in Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle’s Medium (DMEM) supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum (FBS, HyClone SV30160.03), penicillin/streptomycin (100 U/mL, PAN Biotech GmBH P06-07040), and l-glutamine (2 mM, Caisson GLL01) at 37 °C in 5% CO2.The cells were incubated for 4 days with different concentrations of the compounds. Culture media was removed, and cells were washed with phosphate buffered saline (PBS). The remaining adherent cells were stained with 0.2% crystal violet in 2% ethanol for 10 min, rinsed gently, and dried in an oven. Then 1% sodium dodecyl sulfate was added to solubilize the stained cells. Absorbances were taken at 570 nm using a spectrophotometer (Tecan Ultra 384, Mannedorf, Switzerland).

    Determination of Cell Proliferation Inhibition by the MTS Assay

    Human breast cancer MDA-MB231 cells were purchased from ATCC (Rockville, MD) and grown in Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle Medium (DMEM, Sigma-Aldrich, Singapore), which was supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 50 μg/mL penicillin, and 50 μg/mL streptomycin at 37 °C, 5% CO2. The cells were subcultured to 80–90% confluency and used within 15–20 passages for the assay. Cell viability was assessed with CellTiter 96 Aqueous One solution (Promega, Madison, WI), which contained the tetrazolium salt MTS. MDA-MB-231 cells were seeded at 500 cells per well in a 96-well plate for 24 h. Aliquots of test compounds (initially prepared as 50 mM stock solutions in DMSO) were added to each well, and the plates were incubated for 72 h. The final amount of DMSO per well was maintained at 0.5% v/v. At the end of the incubation period, 20 μL per well of MTS solution was added and the plates were incubated for another 3 h before absorbance readings were read on a microplate reader (Tecan Infinite M200) at 490 nm. Cell viability was determined from readings of treated wells compared to control wells (absence of test compound) with correction of background absorbance. The IC50 (concentration required to reduce cell viability to 50% of control/untreated cells) was determined in triplicates on separate occasions, using two different stock solutions. Percent viability readings for each test compound were plotted against log concentration on GraphPad Prism (version 5.0, GraphPad Software, San Diego, CA), with constraints set at ≥0 and ≤100%. A sigmoidal curve was generated from which each IC50 was obtained.

    Determination of Cell Proliferation Inhibition by the MTT Assay

    Human breast cancer MCF7 cells were purchased from ATCC (Rockville, MD) and grown in RPMI Media (Sigma-Aldrich, Singapore), which was supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 50 μg/mL penicillin, and 50 μg/mL streptomycin at 37 °C, 5% CO2. The cells were subcultured to 80–90% confluency and used within 15–20 passages for the assay. Cell viability was assessed with MTT (3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyl tetrazolium bromide), and MCF7 cells were seeded at 500 cells per well in a 96-well plate for 24 h. Aliquots of test compounds (initially prepared as 50 mM stock solutions in DMSO) were added to each well, and the plates were incubated for 72 h. The final amount of DMSO per well was maintained at 0.5% v/v. At the end of the incubation period, the media was then removed and replaced with FBS free media (150 μL) and MTT (50 μL of 2 mg/mL solution in phosphate buffer saline, pH 7.4). After incubation (3 h) at 37 °C, 5% CO2, the supernatant was removed and a solution of 100 μL of DMSO was added to dissolve the formazan crystals. Absorbance was measured at 570 nm on a microplate reader (Tecan Infinite 200). Cell viability was determined from readings of treated wells compared to control wells (absence of test compound) with correction of background absorbance. The IC50 (concentration required to reduce cell viability to 50% of control/untreated cells) was determined in triplicates on separate occasions, using two different stock solutions. Percent viability readings for each test compound were plotted against log concentration on GraphPad Prism (version 5.0, GraphPad Software, San Diego, CA), with constraints set at ≥0 and ≤100%. A sigmoidal curve was generated from which each IC50 was obtained.

    Determination of Toxicity in Transforming Growth Factor-α Mouse Hepatocyte (TAMH) Cells

    TAMH cells were seeded at a cell density of 12000 cells/well (60000 cells/mL) in a 96-well plate (NUNC) a day before drug treatment. Cells were then treated test compounds starting from a concentration of 100 μM (0.5% DMSO concentration: 0.5 μL of drug in 99.5 μL of media in each well; drug stock concentration is 10 mM). Drug-treated cells were then incubated at 37 °C for 24 h, after which time cell viability was determined with CellTiter-Glo cell viability assay (Promega Corporation) as per manufacturer’s instructions. The cell-reagent mixture was then transferred to a solid white flat-bottom 96-well plate (Greiner). Luminescence was then recorded with an integration time of 0.25 s (Tecan Infinite M200 microplate reader). Either percentage inhibition at the top concentration or an IC50 was calculated.

    Determination of Toxicity in AC10 Human Cardiomyocyte Cells

    AC10 cells were seeded at a cell density of 5000 cells/well (75000 cells/mL) in a 96-well plate (NUNC) a day before drug treatment. Cells were then treated as for TAMH assay.

    Procedure for the Intracellular pH (pHi) Measurement

    pHi was measured using 2′,7′-bis(2-carboxyethyl)-5-(and-6)-carboxyfluorescein–acetoxymethyl (BCECF-AM) (Invitrogen (B1170)). After 48 h of compound treatment, cells were stained with 2 μM BCECF-AM for 10 min in 1× Ringer’s solution (2.2 mM CaCl2, 5.6 mM KCl, 154 mM NaCl, 2.4 mM NaHCO3, 2 mM Tris-Cl, pH 7.4) for 10 min at 37 °C with 5% CO2. Cells were then washed with 1× Ringer’s solution and incubated in 1× Ringer’s solution during imaging using confocal microscopy. Fluorescence signals were obtained at pH insensitive 405 nm and pH sensitive 488 nm, and the emitted intensity was measured at 500 nm. pHi of each cell line was calculated from an in situ three-point calibration curve of fluorescence ratio F488/F405 of pH 6.5, pH 7.0, and pH 7.5 calibration buffer (125 mM KCl, 1 mM MgCl2, 1 mM CaCl2, 20 mM Hepes sodium free buffer with pH adjusted using hydrochloric acid (HCl) or potassium hydroxide (KOH)) in 10 μM nigericin (Sigma, N7143).

    Procedure for In Vitro Microplate Assay

    MCF7 cells were seeded at 15000 cells/well in a 96-well plate (in triplicates). Probe 21 (20 μM) was added and cells incubated for 3 h at 37 °C. Cells were then washed with PBS (3×), and exogenous H2S donors were added. Fluorescence was read at ex620/em680 at 37 °C over time.

    Procedure for Confocal Imaging

    MCF7 cells were seeded at 20000 cells/well in an 8-chamber plate (0.8 cm2). Probe 21 (20 μM) was added and cells incubated for 2 h at 37 °C. Cells were then washed with PBS (3×), and exogenous H2S donors were added and incubated for 5 h. Fluorescent images of the live cells were obtained using a confocal fluorescence microscope FV 1000 and processed using Olympus Fluoview Ver.3.1. Viewer (Olympus, Tokyo, Japan).

    Procedure for Kinetic Solubility

    Kinetic solubilities of compounds were determined using multiscreen filter plates from Millipore (PCF Filter Plate MSSLBPC10). Briefly, a saturated solution of test compound was prepared in universal buffer pH 7.4 (1% DMSO, v/v), agitated for a fixed period of time, filtered, and the concentration of the filtrate determined by UV absorbance using 96-well plates (Corning flat bottom transparent UV plate FIS no. 07-200-623) to give an estimate of solubility.

    Procedure for Determination of Permeability

    Effective permeability (Pe) of test compounds was determined by the parallel artificial membrane permeation assay (PAMPA), which is widely employed in the pharmaceutical industry to predict oral absorption potential of early drug candidates. The Pe of five standard compounds (caffeine, carbamazepine, quinidine, verapamil, warfarin, and propranolol) were determined under similar experimental conditions as each test compound and complied with literature reported studies.(89, 90) Briefly, a standard curve of each test compound was prepared from 50 mM DMSO stock solutions diluted with 1× PBS (top concentration of 500 μM, final DMSO concentration 1%). UV absorbance of test compounds was measured at 260 nm in 96-well plates (Corning FIS no. 07-200-623). A 1% solution (w/v, 5 μL) of lecithin in dodecane was was pipetted into the well of a donor plate (MultiScreen-IP PAMPA assay plates (MAIPNTR10, Millipore)), then 300 μL of a 500 μM solution of test compound was added. Then 300 μL of 1× PBS buffer (1% DMSO) was added to a MultiScreen Receiver Plate (MATRNPS50, Millipore), and the two plates were placed together in contact in an airtight container and agitated in an incubator (250 rpm, 6 or 16 h) at a temperature of 22.5 °C (±2.5 °C). Absorbance of the solutions was measured at 260 nm and Pe calculated (see Supporting Information).

    Procedure for AMES Test

    Growing of bacterial cultures: S. typhimurium strains were grown from bacterial discs in nutrient broth at 37 °C in a shaking incubator (∼150 rpm) for about 10 h. The cultures were then measured for absorbance with a UV spectrophotometer at 660 nm (required density of approximately 1.0–1.2 absorbance reading).
    Drug treatment genotoxicity assay: The top agar was melted in a hot water bath or microwave oven, and 2 mL was aliquoted into culture tubes maintained at 45 °C for at least 30 to 45 min. Solvent control DMSO (100 μL) and positive control 2-aminoanthracene (10 and 5 μg) were added to separate tubes containing top agar. Test compounds (100 μL of 1 mM solutions) were added to separate tubes containing top agar. S9 mix (500 μL, MOLTOX Inc.) was added to all tubes containing either controls or test compounds. Then 100 μL of S. typhimurium strain (either TA98 or TA100) was added to the top agar, which was immediately mixed and decanted onto a Minimal Glucose Agar Plate and swirled to obtain an even distribution of plating mixture over the agar surface. After agar hardened, the plates were then incubated at 37 °C for 48 h. Colonies were counted and recorded.

    Procedure for MCF7 and MCF10A Cell Viability Assays

    MCF10A and MCF7 cells were seeded onto a 48-well plate in triplicates at 7000 cells per well. The cells were treated with either 1 or 22 at the indicated concentrations for 72 h. Cell survival was determined by crystal violet assay, whereby the cells were rinsed once with PBS and incubated with 0.2% crystal violet in 2% ethanol for 10 min. The crystal violet was dissolved in 1% SDS, and absorbance was measured at 570 nm using a spectrophotometer (Tecan Ultra 384).

    Procedure for Tumor Spheroid Assay

    MCF7 cells were seeded onto a 96-well round-bottomed ultra low attachment plate (ULA, Corning) in triplicates at 200 cells per well. After 2 days of incubation without disturbance, the spheroid was treated with 1 and 22 at 100, 200, 400, and 800 μM concentrations. Images were captured using an inverted microscope (Olympus IX-81) on the indicated days post-treatment. The diameter of each tumor spheroid was measured using Image-Pro Analyzer 6.2 software. The spheroid sizes of treated tumor spheroids were compared with those of untreated spheroids.

    Procedure for Apoptosis Analysis

    MCF7 cells were treated with either 1 or 22 at the indicated concentrations for 72 h. Cells, both live and dead populations, were collected and lysed in RIPA lysis buffer [20 mM Tris/HCl (pH 7.4), 127 mM NaCl, 0.1% SDS, 0.5% deoxycholate, 1% Triton X-100, and 2 mM EDTA]. The amount of protein was quantified using the Bradford protein assay. Rabbit anticleaved PARP (Asp 214, D64E10, 1:1000 dilution, 89 kDa, Cell Signaling Technology), rabbit anticleaved caspase 7 (Asp 198, 1:1000 dilution, 20 kDa, Cell Signaling Technology), and rabbit anti-GAPDH (1:3000 dilution, 36 kDa, Santa Cruz Biotechnology) antibodies were used for immunoblotting.

    This article references 90 other publications.

    1. 1
      Wang, R. Physiological implications of hydrogen sulfide: a whiff exploration that blossomed Physiol. Rev. 2012, 92, 791– 896 DOI: 10.1152/physrev.00017.2011
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Physiological implications of hydrogen sulfide: a whiff exploration that blossomed
      Wang, Rui
      Physiological Reviews (2012), 92 (2), 791-896CODEN: PHREA7; ISSN:0031-9333. (American Physiological Society)
      A review. The important life-supporting role of hydrogen sulfide (H2S) has evolved from bacteria to plants, invertebrates, vertebrates, and finally to mammals. Over the centuries, however, H2S had only been known for its toxicity and environmental hazard. Physiol. importance of H2S has been appreciated for about a decade. It started by the discovery of endogenous H2S prodn. in mammalian cells and gained momentum by typifying this gasotransmitter with a variety of physiol. functions. The H2S-catalyzing enzymes are differentially expressed in cardiovascular, neuronal, immune, renal, respiratory, gastrointestinal, reproductive, liver, and endocrine systems and affect the functions of these systems through the prodn. of H2S. The physiol. functions of H2S are mediated by different mol. targets, such as different ion channels and signaling proteins. Alternations of H2S metab. lead to an array of pathol. disturbances in the form of hypertension, atherosclerosis, heart failure, diabetes, cirrhosis, inflammation, sepsis, neurodegenerative disease, erectile dysfunction, and asthma, to name a few. Many new technologies have been developed to detect endogenous H2S prodn., and novel H2S-delivery compds. have been invented to aid therapeutic intervention of diseases related to abnormal H2S metab. While acknowledging the challenges ahead, research on H2S physiol. and medicine is entering an exponential exploration era.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XptF2kur0%253D&md5=0f2aa4a16c8557475056f604455271e0

      Guo, H.; Gai, J. W.; Wang, Y.; Jin, H. F.; Du, J. B.; Jin, J. Characterization of hydrogen sulfide and its synthases, cystathionine beta-synthase and cystathionine gamma-lyase, in human prostatic tissue and cells Urology 2012, 79 (483) e1– e5 DOI: 10.1016/j.urology.2011.10.013
      [Crossref], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
    4. 4
      Shibuya, N.; Mikami, Y.; Kimura, Y.; Nagahara, N.; Kimura, H. Vascular endothelium expresses 3-mercaptopyruvate sulfurtransferase and produces hydrogen sulfide J. Biochem. 2009, 146, 623– 6 DOI: 10.1093/jb/mvp111
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Vascular Endothelium Expresses 3-Mercaptopyruvate Sulfurtransferase and Produces Hydrogen Sulfide
      Shibuya, Norihiro; Mikami, Yoshinori; Kimura, Yuka; Nagahara, Noriyuki; Kimura, Hideo
      Journal of Biochemistry (2009), 146 (5), 623-626CODEN: JOBIAO; ISSN:0021-924X. (Japanese Biochemical Society)
      Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) has been recognized as a smooth muscle relaxant. Cystathionine γ-lyase, which is localized to smooth muscle, is thought to be the major H2S-producing enzyme in the thoracic aorta. Here we show that 3-mercaptopyruvate sulfurtransferase (3MST) and cysteine aminotransferase (CAT) are localized to vascular endothelium in the thoracic aorta and produce H2S. Both 3MST and CAT were localized to endothelium. Lysates of vascular endothelial cells produced H2S from cysteine and α-ketoglutarate. The present study provides a new insight into the prodn. and release of H2S as a smooth muscle relaxant from vascular endothelium.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtlyrtrfK&md5=6342f6d07915d9321fb1b1e48e4539be
    5. 5
      Pan, T. T.; Feng, Z. N.; Lee, S. W.; Moore, P. K.; Bian, J. S. Endogenous hydrogen sulfide contributes to the cardioprotection by metabolic inhibition preconditioning in the rat ventricular myocytes J. Mol. Cell. Cardiol. 2006, 40, 119– 30 DOI: 10.1016/j.yjmcc.2005.10.003
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      Endogenous hydrogen sulfide contributes to the cardioprotection by metabolic inhibition preconditioning in the rat ventricular myocytes
      Pan, Ting-Ting; Feng, Zhan-Ning; Lee, Shiau Wei; Moore, Philip Keith; Bian, Jin-Song
      Journal of Molecular and Cellular Cardiology (2006), 40 (1), 119-130CODEN: JMCDAY; ISSN:0022-2828. (Elsevier B.V.)
      The possible role of hydrogen sulfide (H2S) in cardioprotection was investigated in isolated rat ventricular myocytes exposed to severe metabolic inhibition (MI) in glucose-free buffer contg. 2-deoxy-D-glucose (2-DOG), an inhibitor of glycolysis. Pretreatment (30 min) with NaHS (a H2S donor) at concns. of 10-5 to 10-4 mol/L caused a concn. related increase in cell viability and the ratio of rod-shaped cells. A time course study showed that NaHS-induced cardioprotection occurred in 2 time windows (∼1 h and 16-28 h). To observe whether endogenous H2S may be involved in the delayed cardioprotection response of IP, DL-propargylglycine (PAG) and β-cyano-L-alanine (BCA; two inhibitors of H2S biosynthesis) were used. Both drugs significantly attenuated the cardioprotection produced by MI using cell viability, cellular injury index, and elec.-induced [Ca2+]i transients as end-points. These data suggest that endogenous H2S plays an important role in the cardioprotection following MI preconditioning. In an attempt to det. the mechanism of the cardioprotective effect of H2S, we examd. the effect of blocking KATP channels with glibenclamide (a non-selective KATP channel blocker), 5-hydroxydecanoic acid (5-HD, a mitochondrial KATP blocker), and HMR-1098 (a sarcolemmal KATP blocker). The cardioprotective effects of NaHS were significantly attenuated by glibenclamide and HMR-1098 treatment but not by 5-HD. Inhibition of NO prodn. with L-NG nitroarginine Me ester (L-NAME) also attenuated the cardioprotection of NaHS. In conclusion, our findings provide the first evidence that H2S may protect the heart most probably by activating sarcolemmal KATP channels and/or provoking NO release and the cardioprotective effects of metabolic ischemic preconditioning is, at least partially, mediated by endogenous H2S.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XkvFeh&md5=555bbffd1a5da8f6cc3275060a4641ba
    6. 6
      Sodha, N. R.; Clements, R. T.; Feng, J.; Liu, Y.; Bianchi, C.; Horvath, E. M.; Szabo, C.; Stahl, G. L.; Sellke, F. W. Hydrogen sulfide therapy attenuates the inflammatory response in a porcine model of myocardial ischemia/reperfusion injury J. Thorac. Cardiovasc. Surg. 2009, 138, 977– 84 DOI: 10.1016/j.jtcvs.2008.08.074
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Hydrogen sulfide therapy attenuates the inflammatory response in a porcine model of myocardial ischemia/reperfusion injury
      Sodha, Neel R.; Clements, Richard T.; Feng, Jun; Liu, Yuhong; Bianchi, Cesario; Horvath, Eszter M.; Szabo, Csaba; Stahl, Gregory L.; Sellke, Frank W.
      Journal of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery (2009), 138 (4), 977-984CODEN: JTCSAQ; ISSN:0022-5223. (Elsevier)
      Hydrogen sulfide is produced endogenously in response to myocardial ischemia and thought to be cardioprotective. The mechanism underlying this protection has yet to be fully elucidated, but it may be related to sulfide's ability to limit inflammation. This study investigates the cardioprotection provided by exogenous hydrogen sulfide and its potential anti-inflammatory mechanism of action. The mid left anterior descending coronary artery in 14 Yorkshire swine was acutely occluded for 60 min, followed by reperfusion for 120 min. Controls (n = 7) received placebo, and treatment animals (n = 7) received sulfide 10 min before and throughout reperfusion. Hemodynamic and functional measurements were obtained. Evans blue and tri-Ph tetrazolium chloride staining identified the area at risk and infarction. Coronary microvascular reactivity was assessed. Tissue was assayed for myeloperoxidase activity and proinflammatory cytokines. Pre-ischemia/reperfusion hemodynamics were similar between groups, whereas post-ischemia/reperfusion mean arterial pressure was reduced by 28.7 ± 5.0 mm Hg in controls vs. 6.7 ± 6.2 mm Hg in treatment animals (P = .03). Pos. first deriv. of left ventricular pressure over time was reduced by 1325 ± 455 mm Hg/s in controls versys 416 ± 207 mm Hg/s in treatment animals (P = .002). Segmental shortening in the area at risk was better in treatment animals. Infarct size (percent of area at risk) in controls was 41.0% ± 7.8% vs. 21.2% ± 2.5% in the treated group (P = .036). Tissue levels of interleukin 6, interleukin 8, tumor necrosis factor-alpha, and myeloperoxidase activity decreased in the treatment group. Treated animals demonstrated improved microvascular reactivity. Therapeutic sulfide provides protection in response to ischemia/reperfusion injury, improving myocardial function, reducing infarct size, and improving coronary microvascular reactivity, potentially through its anti-inflammatory properties. Exogenous sulfide may have therapeutic utility in clin. settings in which ischemia/reperfusion injury is encountered.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtFGgu7fP&md5=52c79f76040422305943c80f1c4e0d38

Exogenous hydrogen sulfide attenuates diabetic myocardial injury through cardiac mitochondrial protection Mol. Cell. Biochem. 2012, 371, 187– 98 DOI: 10.1007/s11010-012-1435-3

      Li, L.; Moore, P. K. Could hydrogen sulfide be the next blockbuster treatment for inflammatory disease? Expert Rev. Clin. Pharmacol. 2013, 6, 593– 5 DOI: 10.1586/17512433.2013.842126
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Could hydrogen sulfide be the next blockbuster treatment for inflammatory disease?
      Li, Ling; Moore, Philip K.
      Expert Review of Clinical Pharmacology (2013), 6 (6), 593-595CODEN: ERCPAG; ISSN:1751-2433. (Expert Reviews Ltd.)
      A review is given on the role of hydrogen sulfide (H2S) as a mediator of inflammation and beneficial effects of H2S donors as antiinflammatory agents.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhs1yisbfE&md5=6482d1a4b9a8533ffaded45e3f7eec10
    9. 9
      Li, L.; Bhatia, M.; Zhu, Y. Z.; Zhu, Y. C.; Ramnath, R. D.; Wang, Z. J.; Anuar, F. B.; Whiteman, M.; Salto-Tellez, M.; Moore, P. K. Hydrogen sulfide is a novel mediator of lipopolysaccharide-induced inflammation in the mouse FASEB J. 2005, 19, 1196– 8 DOI: 10.1096/fj.04-3583fje
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Hydrogen sulfide is a novel mediator of lipopolysaccharide-induced inflammation in the mouse
      Li, Ling; Bhatia, Madhav; Zhu, Yi Zhun; Zhu, Yi Chun; Raninath, Raina Devi; Wang, Zhong Jing; Anuar, Farhana Binte Mohammed; Whiteman, Matthew; Salto-Tellez, Manuel; Moore, Philip K.
      FASEB Journal (2005), 19 (9), 1196-1198, 10.1096/fj.04-3583fjeCODEN: FAJOEC; ISSN:0892-6638. (Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology)
      Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) is synthesized in the body from L-cysteine by several enzymes including cystathionine-γ-lyase (CSE). To date, there is little information about the potential role of H2S in inflammation. The authors have now investigated the part played by H2S in endotoxin-induced inflammation in the mouse. E. coli lipopolysaccharide (LPS) administration produced a dose (10 and 20 mg/kg i.p.)- and time (6 and 24 h)-dependent increase in plasma H2S concn. LPS (10 mg/kg i.p., 6 h) increased plasma H2S concn. from 34.1 μM to 40.9 μM while H2S formation from added L-cysteine was increased in both liver and kidney. CSE gene expression was also increased in both liver (94.2%) and kidney (77.5%). LPS injection also elevated lung (148.2%) and kidney (78.8%) myeloperoxidase (MPO, a marker of tissue neutrophil infiltration) activity alongside histol. evidence of lung, liver, and kidney tissue inflammatory damage. Plasma nitrate/nitrite (NOx) concn. was addnl. elevated in a time- and dose-dependent manner in LPS-injected animals. To examine directly the possible proinflammatory effect of H2S, mice were administered sodium hydrosulfide (H2S donor drug, 14 μmol/kg i.p.) that resulted in marked histol. signs of lung inflammation, increased lung and liver MPO activity, and raised plasma TNF-α concn. (4.6 ng/mL). In contrast, DL-propargylglycine (CSE inhibitor, 50 mg/kg i.p.), exhibited marked anti-inflammatory activity as evidenced by reduced lung and liver MPO activity, and ameliorated lung and liver tissue damage. In sep. expts., the authors also detected significantly higher (150.5 μM c.f. 43.8 μM) plasma H2S levels in humans with septic shock. These findings suggest that H2S exhibits proinflammatory activity in endotoxic shock and suggest a new approach to the development of novel drugs for this condition.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXlvFens7g%253D&md5=39e471b8094df298a89791bc9ecbca1d
    10. 10
      Fiorucci, S. Hydrogen sulfide: from physiology to pharmacology Inflammation Allergy: Drug Targets 2011, 10, 77– 84 DOI: 10.2174/187152811794776277
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Hydrogen sulfide: from physiology to pharmacology
      Fiorucci, Stefano
      Inflammation & Allergy: Drug Targets (2011), 10 (2), 77-84CODEN: IADTAQ; ISSN:1871-5281. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
      A review. Gaseous neurotransmitters are a growing family of enzymically generated gaseous mediators that exert regulatory functions in mammals. It is now widely recognized that hydrogen sulfide (H2S), along with nitric oxide (NO) and carbon monoxide (CO), is an important signaling mol. in cardiovascular, nervous, gastrointestinal, liver and lung physiol. and pharmacol. The prodn. of H2S from L-cysteine is catalyzed primarily by two enzymes, cystathionine-γ-lyase and cystathionine β-synthase. Evidence is accumulating to demonstrate that H2S delivered exogenously exerts beneficial effects in animal models of inflammation and pain highlighting the potential for the therapeutic exploitation of H2S. Several hybrids have been developed coupling an H2S-releasing moiety to conventional drugs. These mol. hybrids are currently evaluated for efficacy in animal models of gastrointestinal, cardiovascular and neurol. disorders and erectile dysfunction. The anti-inflammatory activity of H2S has also been exploited for generating anti-platelets and anti-inflammatory agents that inhibit cyclo-oxygenases while sparing the gastrointestinal and cardiovascular tract.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXktlaktr4%253D&md5=f1383f34a35ac63c219fbab223b09647
    11. 11
      Mani, S.; Untereiner, A.; Wu, L.; Wang, R. Hydrogen sulfide and the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis Antioxid. Redox Signaling 2014, 20, 805– 17 DOI: 10.1089/ars.2013.5324
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      Hydrogen sulfide and the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis
      Mani Sarathi; Untereiner Ashley; Wu Lingyun; Wang Rui
      Antioxidants & redox signaling (2014), 20 (5), 805-17 ISSN:.
      SIGNIFICANCE: Stigmatized as a toxic environmental pollutant for centuries, hydrogen sulfide (H2S) has gained recognition over the last decade as an important gasotransmitter that functions in physiological and pathophysiological conditions, such as atherosclerosis. RECENT ADVANCES: Atherosclerosis is a common disease that stems from the buildup of fatty/cholesterol plaques on the endothelial cells of arteries. The deposits mitigate thickening and stiffening of arterial tissue, which contributes to concomitant systemic or localized vascular disorders. Recently, it has been recognized that H2S plays an anti-atherosclerotic role, and its deficiency leads to early development and progression of atherosclerosis. This review article presents multiple lines of evidence for the protective effects of H2S against the development of atherosclerosis. Also highlighted are the characterization of altered metabolism of H2S in the development of atherosclerosis, underlying molecular and cellular mechanisms, and potential therapeutic intervention based on H2S supplementation for atherosclerosis management. CRITICAL ISSUES: Although a protective role of H2S against atherosclerosis has emerged, controversy remains regarding the mechanisms underlying H2S-induced endothelial cell proliferation and angiogenesis as well as its anti-inflammatory properties. The therapeutic value of H2S to this pathophysiological condition has not been tested clinically but, nonetheless, it shows tremendous promise. FUTURE DIRECTIONS: The efficiency and safety profile of H2S-based therapeutic approaches should be refined, and the mechanisms by which H2S exerts its beneficial effects should be elucidated to develop more specific and potent therapeutic strategies to treat atherosclerosis. Whether the therapeutic effects of H2S in animal studies are transferable to clinical studies merits future investigation.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC3srkvVWkug%253D%253D&md5=ada7cdd714835d522fdc9997525ba11f
    12. 12
      Mani, S.; Li, H.; Untereiner, A.; Wu, L.; Yang, G.; Austin, R. C.; Dickhout, J. G.; Lhotak, S.; Meng, Q. H.; Wang, R. Decreased endogenous production of hydrogen sulfide accelerates atherosclerosis Circulation 2013, 127, 2523– 34 DOI: 10.1161/CIRCULATIONAHA.113.002208
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12
      Decreased Endogenous Production of Hydrogen Sulfide Accelerates Atherosclerosis
      Mani, Sarathi; Li, Hongzhu; Untereiner, Ashley; Wu, Lingyun; Yang, Guangdong; Austin, Richard C.; Dickhout, Jeffrey G.; Lhotak, Sarka; Meng, Qing H.; Wang, Rui
      Circulation (2013), 127 (25), 2523-2534CODEN: CIRCAZ; ISSN:0009-7322. (Lippincott Williams & Wilkins)
      BACKGROUND-: Cystathionine γ-lyase (CSE) produces hydrogen sulfide (H2S) in the cardiovascular system. The deficiency of CSE in mice leads to a decreased endogenous H2S level, an age-dependent increase in blood pressure, and impaired endothelium-dependent vasorelaxation. To date, there is no direct evidence for a causative role of altered metab. of endogenous H2S in atherosclerosis development. METHODS AND RESULTS-: Six-week-old CSE gene knockout and wild-type mice were fed with either a control chow or atherogenic paigen-type diet for 12 wk. Plasma lipid profile and homocysteine levels, blood pressure, oxidative stress, atherosclerotic lesion size in the aortic roots, cell proliferation, and adhesion mol. expression were then analyzed. CSE-knockout mice fed with atherogenic diet developed early fatty streak lesions in the aortic root, elevated plasma levels of cholesterol and low-d. lipoprotein cholesterol, hyperhomocysteinemia, increased lesional oxidative stress and adhesion mol. expression, and enhanced aortic intimal proliferation. Treatment of CSE-knockout mice with NaHS, but not N-acetylcysteine or ezetimibe, inhibited the accelerated atherosclerosis development. Double knockout of CSE and apolipoprotein E gene expression in mice exacerbated atherosclerosis development more than that in the mice with only apolipoprotein E or CSE knockout. CONCLUSIONS-: Endogenously synthesized H2S protects vascular tissues from atherogenic damage by reducing vessel intimal proliferation and inhibiting adhesion mol. expression. Decreased endogenous H2S prodn. predisposes the animals to vascular remodeling and early development of atherosclerosis. The CSE/H2S pathway is an important therapeutic target for protection against atherosclerosis.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtVWmtLfF&md5=f02ee9f5fb2b4641e774c28d769c2b35
    13. 13
      Abe, K.; Kimura, H. The possible role of hydrogen sulfide as an endogenous neuromodulator J. Neurosci. 1996, 16, 1066– 1071
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13
      The possible role of hydrogen sulfide as an endogenous neuromodulator
      Abe, Kazuho; Kimura, Hideo
      Journal of Neuroscience (1996), 16 (3), 1066-71CODEN: JNRSDS; ISSN:0270-6474. (Society for Neuroscience)
      In this work we show the following: (1) an H2S-producing enzyme, cystathionine β-synthase (CBS), is highly expressed in the hippocampus; (2) CBS inhibitors hydroxylamine and aminooxyacetate suppress the prodn. of brain H2S; and (3) a CBS activator, S-adenosyl-L-methionine, enhances H2S prodn., indicating that CBS contributes to the prodn. of endogenous H2S. We also show that physiol. concns. of H2S selectively enhance NMDA receptor-mediated responses and facilitate the induction of hippocampal long-term potentiation. These observations suggest that endogenous H2S functions as a neuromodulator in the brain.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK28XmsVeluw%253D%253D&md5=55007ff4faa4072e8c27e8c2653d68aa
    14. 14
      Zhong, G.; Chen, F.; Cheng, Y.; Tang, C.; Du, J. The role of hydrogen sulfide generation in the pathogenesis of hypertension in rats induced by inhibition of nitric oxide synthase J. Hypertens. 2003, 21, 1879– 85 DOI: 10.1097/00004872-200310000-00015
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      14
      The role of hydrogen sulfide generation in the pathogenesis of hypertension in rats induced by inhibition of nitric oxide synthase
      Zhong, GuangZhen; Chen, FengRong; Cheng, YouQin; Tang, ChaoShu; Du, JunBao
      Journal of Hypertension (2003), 21 (10), 1879-1885CODEN: JOHYD3; ISSN:0263-6352. (Lippincott Williams & Wilkins)
      The present study intended to investigate whether the impaired H2S synthase/H2S pathway is assocd. with hypertension. Hypertension in Wistar rats was induced by the oral administration of the L-Arg analog, NG-nitro-L-Arg Me ester (L-NAME) in their drinking water for a period of 6 wk. The control rats were given plain tap water only. NaHS was given by i.p. injection to both the control group and the L-NAME-treated group. The systolic BP (blood pressure) was measured by a tail-cuff method using a pulse transducer. Plasma H2S and H2S generation by thoracic aorta and superior mesenteric artery, were detd. In addn., the activity of cystathionine-γ-lyase (CSE) in thoracic aorta and superior mesenteric artery, most responsible for H2S prodn., was also measured. Competitive reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) was used to det. CSE mRNA in thoracic aorta. L-NAME caused a time-dependent elevation of systolic BP. The heart-to-body wt. ratio of L-NAME-treated rats was 27% higher than that of controls. The systolic BP in the NaHS-treated L-NAME group was significantly decreased, by 19% (P < 0.01), in comparison with the L-NAME group. The heart-to-body wt. ratio decreased significantly by 12%. L-NAME inhibited CSE gene expression significantly. The inhibition of H2S generation and CSE activity by L-NAME was greatly attenuated in the NaHS-treated L-NAME group. However, there was no significant difference in NO generation between the L-NAME group and the NaHS-treated L-NAME group. In summary, dysfunction of the vascular H2S synthase/H2S pathway was found in L-NAME-induced hypertensive rats. Exogenous H2S effectively prevented the development of hypertension induced by L-NAME. These findings suggest that the H2S synthase/H2S pathway participates in hypertension.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXnsFSnsr8%253D&md5=6ccfa55e326a4cc1220c3424162474e5
    15. 15
      Mok, Y.-Y. P.; Atan, M. S.; Ping, C. Y.; Jing, W. Z.; Bhatia, M.; Moochhala, S.; Moore, P. K. Role of hydrogen sulphide in haemorrhagic shock in the rat: protective effect of inhibitors of hydrogen sulphide biosynthesis Br. J. Pharmacol. 2004, 143, 881– 889 DOI: 10.1038/sj.bjp.0706014
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      15
      Role of hydrogen sulphide in haemorrhagic shock in the rat: Protective effect of inhibitors of hydrogen sulphide biosynthesis
      Mok, Ying-Yuan Pamela; Bin Mohammed Atan, Mohammed Shirhan; Ping, Cheong Yoke; Jing, Wang Zhong; Bhatia, Madhav; Moochhala, Shabbir; Moore, Philip K.
      British Journal of Pharmacology (2004), 143 (7), 881-889CODEN: BJPCBM; ISSN:0007-1188. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Hemorrhagic shock (60 min) in the anesthetized rat resulted in a prolonged fall in the mean arterial blood pressure (MAP) and heart rate (HR). Pretreatment (30 min before shock) or posttreatment (60 min after shock) with inhibitors of cystathionine γ lyase (CSE; converts cysteine into hydrogen sulfide (H2S)), dl-propargylglycine (PAG) or β-cyanoalanine (BCA) (50 mg kg-1, i.v.), or glibenclamide (40 mg kg-1, i.p.), produced a rapid, partial restoration in MAP and HR. Neither saline nor DMSO affected MAP or HR. Plasma H2S concn. was elevated 60 min after blood withdrawal (37.5±1.3 μm, n = 18 c.f. 28.9±1.4 μm, n = 15, P<0.05). The conversion of cysteine to H2S by liver (but not kidney) homogenates prepd. from animals killed 60 min after withdrawal of blood was significantly increased (52.1±1.6 c.f. 39.8±4.1 nmol mg protein-1, n = 8, P<0.05), as was liver CSE mRNA (2.7 ×). Both PAG (IC50, 55.0±3.2 μm) and BCA (IC50, 6.5±1.2 μm) inhibited liver H2S synthesizing activity in vitro. Pretreatment of animals with PAG or BCA (50 mg kg-1, i.p.) but not glibenclamide (40 mg kg-1, i.p., KATP channel inhibitor) abolished the rise in plasma H2S in animals exposed to 60 min hemorrhagic shock and prevented the augmented biosynthesis of H2S from cysteine in liver. These results demonstrate that H2S plays a role in hemorrhagic shock in the rat. CSE inhibitors may provide a novel approach to the treatment of hemorrhagic shock.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXhtFGmurjF&md5=bb0a54c8151662af2c0f09a9d81ee8b0
    16. 16
      Kawabata, A.; Ishiki, T.; Nagasawa, K.; Yoshida, S.; Maeda, Y.; Takahashi, T.; Sekiguchi, F.; Wada, T.; Ichida, S.; Nishikawa, H. Hydrogen sulfide as a novel nociceptive messenger Pain 2007, 132, 74– 81 DOI: 10.1016/j.pain.2007.01.026
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      16
      Hydrogen sulfide as a novel nociceptive messenger
      Kawabata, Atsufumi; Ishiki, Tsuyoshi; Nagasawa, Keita; Yoshida, Shigeru; Maeda, Yumi; Takahashi, Tomoko; Sekiguchi, Fumiko; Wada, Tetsuyuki; Ichida, Seiji; Nishikawa, Hiroyuki
      Pain (2007), 132 (1-2), 74-81CODEN: PAINDB; ISSN:0304-3959. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Hydrogen sulfide (H2S), an endogenous gasotransmitter, modulates various biol. events such as inflammation in the mammalian body. The present study investigated possible involvement of H2S in peripheral nociceptive processing. Intraplantar (i.pl.) administration of NaHS, a H2S donor, produced prompt hyperalgesia in rats, accompanied by expression of Fos in the spinal dorsal horn. The H2S-evoked hyperalgesia was blocked by 5,5'-dithio-bis-(2-nitrobenzoic acid) (DTNB), an oxidizing agent, or ethosuximide and mibefradil, T-type Ca2+ channel inhibitors. L-Cysteine, an endogenous source for H2S, given i.pl., also elicited hyperalgesia, an effect being abolished by DL-propargylglycine (PPG) and β-cyanoalanine (BCA), inhibitors of cystathionine-γ-lyase, a H2S synthesizing enzyme. PPG and/or BCA partially inhibited the hyperalgesia induced by i.pl. lipopolysaccharide, an effect being reversed by i.pl. NaHS. In the patch-clamp study using undifferentiated NG108-15 cells that express T-type, but not other types, of Ca2+ channels, NaHS enhanced the currents through the T-type channels, an effect being blocked by DTNB. Thus, H2S appears to function as a novel nociceptive messenger through sensitization of T-type Ca2+ channels in the peripheral tissues, particularly during inflammation.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtFemtLbJ&md5=71d43d615e846556dd1a010c632d4266
    17. 17
      Distrutti, E.; Sediari, L.; Mencarelli, A.; Renga, B.; Orlandi, S.; Antonelli, E.; Roviezzo, F.; Morelli, A.; Cirino, G.; Wallace, J. L.; Fiorucci, S. Evidence that hydrogen sulfide exerts antinociceptive effects in the gastrointestinal tract by activating KATP channels J. Pharmacol. Exp. Ther. 2006, 316, 325– 335 DOI: 10.1124/jpet.105.091595
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      17
      Evidence that hydrogen sulfide exerts antinociceptive effects in the gastrointestinal tract by activating KATP channels
      Distrutti, Eleonora; Sediari, Luca; Mencarelli, Andrea; Renga, Barbara; Orlandi, Stefano; Antonelli, Elisabetta; Roviezzo, Fiorenza; Morelli, Antonio; Cirino, Giuseppe; Wallace, John L.; Fiorucci, Stefano
      Journal of Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics (2006), 316 (1), 325-335CODEN: JPETAB; ISSN:0022-3565. (American Society for Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics)
      Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) functions as a neuromodulator, but whether it modulates visceral perception and pain is unknown. Cystathionine β-synthase (CBS) and cystathionine-γ-lyase (CSE) mediate enzymic generation of H2S in mammalian cells. Here we have investigated the role of H2S in modulating nociception to colorectal distension, a model that mimics some features of the irritable bowel syndrome. Four graded (0.4-1.6 mL of water) colorectal distensions (CRDs) were produced in conscious rats (healthy and postcolitic), and rectal nociception was assessed by measuring the behavioral response during CRD. Healthy rats were administered with sodium hydrogen sulfide (NaHS) (as a source of H2S), L-cysteine, or vehicle. In a second model, we investigated nociception to CRD in rats recovering from a chem. induced acute colitis. We found that CBS and CSE are expressed in the colon and spinal cord. Treating rats with NaHS resulted in a dose-dependent attenuation of CRD-induced nociception with the maximal effect at 60 μmol/kg (p < 0.05). Administration of L-cysteine, a CSE/CBS substrate, reduced rectal sensitivity to CRD (p < 0.05). NaHS-induced antinociception was reversed by glibenclamide, a ATP-sensitive K+ (KATP) channel inhibitor, and Nω-nitro-L-arginine Me ester hydrochloride (L-NAME), a nitric-oxide (NO) synthase inhibitor. The antinociceptive effect of NaHS was maintained during the resoln. of colon inflammation induced by intrarectal administration of a chem. irritant. In summary, these data show that H2S inhibits nociception induced by CRD in both healthy and postcolitic rats. This effect is mediated by KATP channels and NO. H2S-releasing drugs might be beneficial in treating painful intestinal disorders.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhslCjuw%253D%253D&md5=1913418a52b95434d203490cb021e96f
    18. 18
      Fiorucci, S.; Distrutti, E.; Cirino, G.; Wallace, J. L. The emerging roles of hydrogen sulfide in the gastrointestinal tract and liver Gastroenterology 2006, 131, 259– 71 DOI: 10.1053/j.gastro.2006.02.033
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      18
      The emerging roles of hydrogen sulfide in the gastrointestinal tract and liver
      Fiorucci, Stefano; Distrutti, Eleonora; Cirino, Giuseppe; Wallace, John L.
      Gastroenterology (2006), 131 (1), 259-271CODEN: GASTAB; ISSN:0016-5085. (Elsevier Inc.)
      A review. Hydrogen sulfide, like nitric oxide, was best known as a toxic pollutant before becoming recognized as a key regulator of several physiol. processes. In recent years, evidence has accumulated to suggest important roles for hydrogen sulfide as a mediator of several aspects of gastrointestinal and liver function. Moreover, alterations in hydrogen sulfide prodn. could contribute to disorders of the gastrointestinal tract and liver. For example, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs can reduce prodn. of hydrogen sulfide in the stomach, and this has been shown to contribute to the generation of mucosal injury. Hydrogen sulfide has also been shown to play a key role in modulation of visceral hyperalgesia. Inhibitors of hydrogen sulfide synthesis and drugs that can generate safe levels of hydrogen sulfide in vivo have been developed and are permitting interventional studies in exptl. models and, in the near future, humans.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XnvF2gsbc%253D&md5=03b34dfec536857e690402641f4ff6c3

      Yang, G.; Sun, X.; Wang, R. Hydrogen sulfide-induced apoptosis of human aorta smooth muscle cells via the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinases and caspase-3 FASEB J. 2004, 18, 1782– 1784 DOI: 10.1096/fj.04-2279fje
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      19
      Hydrogen sulfide-induced apoptosis of human aorta smooth muscle cells via the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinases and caspase-3
      Yang, Guangdong; Sun, Xianfeng; Wang, Rui
      FASEB Journal (2004), 18 (14), 1782-1784, 10.1096/fj.04-2279fjeCODEN: FAJOEC; ISSN:0892-6638. (Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology)
      The endogenous prodn. of hydrogen sulfide (H2S) and its physiol. functions, including membrane hyperpolarization and smooth muscle cell relaxation, position this gas well in the family of gasotransmitters together with nitric oxide (NO) and carbon monoxide (CO). In this study, we demonstrate that H2S at physiol. relevant concns. induced apoptosis of human aorta smooth muscle cells (HASMCs). Exposure of HASMCs to H2S did not induce necrosis as verified with Trypan blue exclusion and LDH release anal. After inhibiting endogenous H2S prodn., exogenous H2S induced much more significant apoptosis, which was not altered by the presence of albumin or glutathione. H2S treatment increased the activities of ERK and p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK), but not c-Jun N-terminal kinase activity. Suppression of extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) activity, but not of p38 activity, inhibited the H2S-induced apoptosis of HASMCs. The activation of ERK by H2S in HASMCs was accompanied by increased caspase-3 activity. Inhibition of caspase-3 by AC-DEVD-CHO attenuated the H2S-induced cell apoptosis. Inhibition of ERK by U0126 decreased caspase-3 activity, whereas AC-DEVD-CHO did not alter ERK activity. In conclusion, exogenous H2S induces apoptosis of HASMCs, which is significantly affected by the endogenous H2S level. Of the three investigated MAPKs, only ERK played an active role in mediating H2S-induced apoptosis of HASMCs by activating caspase-3. These findings may help reveal novel mechanisms for many diseases linked to H2S-related abnormal cellular proliferation and apoptosis.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXpslehtbo%253D&md5=149db97cb9b327639aba77c0a4a7bae8

    22. 22
      Papapetropoulos, A.; Pyriochou, A.; Altaany, Z.; Yang, G.; Marazioti, A.; Zhou, Z.; Jeschke, M. G.; Branski, L. K.; Herndon, D. N.; Wang, R.; Szabo, C. Hydrogen sulfide is an endogenous stimulator of angiogenesis Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2009, 106, 21972– 7 DOI: 10.1073/pnas.0908047106
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      22
      Hydrogen sulfide is an endogenous stimulator of angiogenesis
      Papapetropoulos, Andreas; Pyriochou, Anastasia; Altaany, Zaid; Yang, Guangdong; Marazioti, Antonia; Zhou, Zongmin; Jeschke, Mark G.; Branski, Ludwik K.; Herndon, David N.; Wang, Rui; Szabo, Csaba
      Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2009), 106 (51), 21972-21977, S21972/1-S21972/5CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
      The goal of the current study was to investigate the role of exogenous and endogenous H2S on neovascularization and wound healing in vitro and in vivo. Incubation of human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) with H2S enhanced their angiogenic potential, evidenced by accelerated cell growth, cell migration, and capillary morphogenesis on Matrigel. Treatment of chicken chorioallantoic membranes (CAMS) with H2S increased vascular length. Exposure of HUVECs to H2S resulted in increased phosphorylation of Akt, ERK1/2, and p38-MAP kinases. The KATP channel blocker, glibenclamide, or the p38 inhibitor, SB 203580, abolished H2S-induced HUVEC motility. Since glibenclamide inhibited H2S-triggered p38 phosphorylation, the authors proposed that KATP channels lay upstream of p38 in this process. When CAMs were treated with H2S biosynthesis inhibitors DL-propylargylglycine or β-cyano-L-alanine, a redn. in vessel length and branching was obsd., indicating that H2S serves as an endogenous stimulator of the angiogenic response. Stimulation of HUVECs with vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) increased H2S release, while pharmacol. inhibition of H2S prodn. or KATP channels or silencing of cystathionine γ-lyase (CSE) attenuated VEGF signaling and migration of HUVECs. Thus, these results implicate endothelial H2S biosynthesis in the pro-angiogenic action of VEGF. Aortic rings isolated from CSE-knockout mice exhibited markedly reduced microvessel formation in response to VEGF when compared to wild-type littermates. Finally, in vivo, topical administration of H2S enhanced wound healing in a rat model, while wound healing was delayed in CSE-/- mice. It was concluded that endogenous and exogenous H2S stimulates HUVEC-related angiogenic properties through a KATP channel/MAPK pathway.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXlt1Wmug%253D%253D&md5=ab73f38c3ed0031d341fec50f72c6136

      Kimura, Y.; Goto, Y.; Kimura, H. Hydrogen sulfide increases glutathione production and suppresses oxidative stress in mitochondria Antioxid. Redox Signaling 2010, 12, 1– 13 DOI: 10.1089/ars.2008.2282
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      24
      Hydrogen sulfide increases glutathione production and suppresses oxidative stress in mitochondria
      Kimura, Yuka; Goto, Yu-Ichi; Kimura, Hideo
      Antioxidants & Redox Signaling (2010), 12 (1), 1-13CODEN: ARSIF2; ISSN:1523-0864. (Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.)
      Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) is a synaptic modulator as well as a neuroprotectant in the brain. We recently showed that H2S protects neurons from oxidative stress by increasing the levels of glutathione (GSH), a major cellular antioxidant, by more than twice that of a control through enhancing the cystine transport. Here we show that H2S enhances the transport of cysteine to increase GSH prodn. more than cystine transport and to redistribute the localization of GSH to mitochondria. The efficiency of GSH prodn. enhanced by H2S is even greater by fourfold under oxidative stress by glutamate. H2S reinstated GSH levels in the fetal brain decreased by ischemia/reperfusion in utero. In addn., Neuro2a cells expressing a mitochondrial H2S-producing enzyme, 3-mercaptopyruvate sulfurtransferase (3MST), along with cysteine aminotransferase (CAT), showed significant resistance to oxidative stress. The present study shows that H2S protects cells from oxidative stress by two mechanisms. It enhances the prodn. of GSH by enhancing cystine/cysteine transporters and redistributes GSH to mitochondria. H2S produced in mitochondria also may directly suppress oxidative stress. It provides a new mechanism of neuroprotection from oxidative stress by H2S.

      Kimura, Y.; Kimura, H. Hydrogen sulfide protects neurons from oxidative stress FASEB J. 2004, 18, 1165– 1167 DOI: 10.1096/fj.04-1815fje

      25
      Hydrogen sulfide protects neurons from oxidative stress
      Kimura, Yuka; Kimura, Hideo
      FASEB Journal (2004), 18 (10), 1165-1167, 10.1096/fj.04-1815fjeCODEN: FAJOEC; ISSN:0892-6638. (Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology)
      Hydrogen sulfide (H2S), which is a well-known toxic gas, is found in relatively high concns. in the brain. Although a neuromodulatory role of H2S has been demonstrated, little is known of its other biol. functions. Here we show that H2S protects primary cultures of neurons from death in a well-studied model of oxidative stress caused by glutamate, a process called oxidative glutamate toxicity-or oxytosis. We found that H2S increases the glutathione levels, which normally decrease during the cell death cascade, by enhancing the activity of γ-glutamylcysteine synthetase and up-regulating cystine transport. Cystine (cysteine) is the rate-limiting substrate of glutathione synthesis. These observations reveal that H2S protects neurons from oxytosis by increasing the prodn. of the antioxidant glutathione.

The synthesis and functional evaluation of a mitochondria-targeted hydrogen sulfide donor, (10-oxo-10-(4-(3-thioxo-3H-1,2-dithiol-5-yl)-phenoxy)decyl)triphenylphosphonium bromide (AP39) MedChemComm 2014, 5, 728 DOI: 10.1039/c3md00323j

    27. 27
      Krishnan, N.; Fu, C.; Pappin, D. J.; Tonks, N. K. H2S-Induced sulfhydration of the phosphatase PTP1B and its role in the endoplasmic reticulum stress response Sci. Signaling 2011, 4, ra86 DOI: 10.1126/scisignal.2002329
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      27
      H2S-Induced sulfhydration of the phosphatase PTP1B and its role in the endoplasmic reticulum stress response
      Krishnan Navasona; Fu Cexiong; Pappin Darryl J; Tonks Nicholas K
      Science signaling (2011), 4 (203), ra86 ISSN:.
      Although originally considered toxic, hydrogen sulfide (H(2)S) has been implicated in mediating various biological processes. Nevertheless, its cellular targets and mode of action are not well understood. Protein tyrosine phosphatases (PTPs), which regulate numerous signal transduction pathways, use an essential cysteine residue at the active site, which is characterized by a low pK(a) and is susceptible to reversible oxidation. Here, we report that PTP1B was reversibly inactivated by H(2)S, in vitro and in cells, through sulfhydration of the active-site cysteine residue. Unlike oxidized PTP1B, the sulfhydrated enzyme was preferentially reduced in vitro by thioredoxin, compared to glutathione or dithiothreitol. Sulfhydration of PTP1B in cells required the presence of cystathionine γ-lyase (CSE), a critical enzyme in H(2)S production, and resulted in inhibition of phosphatase activity. Suppression of CSE decreased H(2)S production and decreased the phosphorylation of tyrosine-619 in PERK [protein kinase-like endoplasmic reticulum (ER) kinase], thus reducing its activation in response to ER stress. PERK, which phosphorylates the eukaryotic translational initiation factor 2, leading to attenuation of protein translation, was a direct substrate of PTP1B. In addition, CSE knockdown led to activation of the nonreceptor tyrosine kinase SRC, previously shown to be mediated by PTP1B. These effects of suppressing H(2)S production on the response to ER stress were abrogated by a small-molecule inhibitor of PTP1B. Together, these data define a signaling function for H(2)S in inhibiting PTP1B activity and thereby promoting PERK activity during the response to ER stress.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC38%252Fns1Ggtw%253D%253D&md5=ba09e84b156f237f6f7b05bdc2f154ea
    28. 28
      Mustafa, A. K.; Gadalla, M. M.; Sen, N.; Kim, S.; Mu, W.; Gazi, S. K.; Barrow, R. K.; Yang, G.; Wang, R.; Snyder, S. H. H2S signals through protein S-sulfhydration Sci. Signaling 2009, 2, ra72 DOI: 10.1126/scisignal.2000464
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      28
      H2S signals through protein S-sulfhydration
      Mustafa Asif K; Gadalla Moataz M; Sen Nilkantha; Kim Seyun; Mu Weitong; Gazi Sadia K; Barrow Roxanne K; Yang Guangdong; Wang Rui; Snyder Solomon H
      Science signaling (2009), 2 (96), ra72 ISSN:.
      Hydrogen sulfide (H2S), a messenger molecule generated by cystathionine gamma-lyase, acts as a physiologic vasorelaxant. Mechanisms whereby H2S signals have been elusive. We now show that H2S physiologically modifies cysteines in a large number of proteins by S-sulfhydration. About 10 to 25% of many liver proteins, including actin, tubulin, and glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH), are sulfhydrated under physiological conditions. Sulfhydration augments GAPDH activity and enhances actin polymerization. Sulfhydration thus appears to be a physiologic posttranslational modification for proteins.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD1MjltlaksQ%253D%253D&md5=be6b1580d8c527476715d84f8b48dc6b
    29. 29
      Yang, G.; Zhao, K.; Ju, Y.; Mani, S.; Cao, Q.; Puukila, S.; Khaper, N.; Wu, L.; Wang, R. Hydrogen sulfide protects against cellular senescence via S-sulfhydration of Keap1 and activation of Nrf2 Antioxid. Redox Signaling 2013, 18, 1906– 19 DOI: 10.1089/ars.2012.4645
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29
      Hydrogen Sulfide Protects Against Cellular Senescence via S-Sulfhydration of Keap1 and Activation of Nrf2
      Yang, Guangdong; Zhao, Kexin; Ju, Youngjun; Mani, Sarathi; Cao, Qiuhui; Puukila, Stephanie; Khaper, Neelam; Wu, Lingyun; Wang, Rui
      Antioxidants & Redox Signaling (2013), 18 (15), 1906-1919CODEN: ARSIF2; ISSN:1523-0864. (Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.)
      Aims: H2S, a third member of gasotransmitter family along with nitric oxide and carbon monoxide, exerts a wide range of cellular and mol. actions in our body. Cystathionine gamma-lyase (CSE) is a major H2S-generating enzyme in our body. Aging at the cellular level, known as cellular senescence, can result from increases in oxidative stress. The aim of this study was to investigate how H2S attenuates oxidative stress and delays cellular senescence. Results: Here we showed that mouse embryonic fibroblasts isolated from CSE knockout mice (CSE KO-MEFs) display increased oxidative stress and accelerated cellular senescence in comparison with MEFs from wild-type mice (WT-MEFs). The protein expression of p53 and p21 was significantly increased in KO-MEFs, and knockdown of p53 or p21 reversed CSE deficiency-induced senescence. Incubation of the cells with NaHS (a H2S donor) significantly increased the glutathione (GSH) level and rescued KO-MEFs from senescence. Nrf2 is a master regulator of the antioxidant response, and Keap1 acts as a neg. regulator of Nrf2. NaHS S-sulfhydrated Keap1 at cysteine-151, induced Nrf2 dissocn. from Keap1, enhanced Nrf2 nuclear translocation, and stimulated mRNA expression of Nrf2-targeted downstream genes, such as glutamate-cysteine ligase and GSH reductase. Innovation: These results provide a mechanistic insight into how H2S signaling mediates cellular senescence induced by oxidative stress. Conclusion: H2S protects against cellular aging via S-sulfhydration of Keap1 and Nrf2 activation in assocn. with oxidative stress.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXlsF2lurk%253D&md5=b6adf3b737edba3c722509d8118e5c53

      Olson, K. R.; DeLeon, E. R.; Liu, F. Controversies and conundrums in hydrogen sulfide biology Nitric Oxide 2014, 41, 11– 26 DOI: 10.1016/j.niox.2014.05.012
      [Crossref], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
    31. 31
      Kashfi, K.; Olson, K. R. Biology and therapeutic potential of hydrogen sulfide and hydrogen sulfide-releasing chimeras Biochem. Pharmacol. 2013, 85, 689– 703 DOI: 10.1016/j.bcp.2012.10.019
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      31
      Biology and therapeutic potential of hydrogen sulfide and hydrogen sulfide-releasing chimeras
      Kashfi, Khosrow; Olson, Kenneth R.
      Biochemical Pharmacology (Amsterdam, Netherlands) (2013), 85 (5), 689-703CODEN: BCPCA6; ISSN:0006-2952. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. Hydrogen sulfide, H2S, is a colorless gas with a strong odor that until recently was only considered to be a toxic environmental pollutant with little or no physiol. significance. However, the past few years have demonstrated its role in many biol. systems and it is becoming increasingly clear that H2S is likely to join nitric oxide (NO) and carbon monoxide (CO) as a major player in mammalian biol. In this review, we have provided an overview of the chem. and biol. of H2S and have summarized the chem. and biol. activity of some natural and synthetic H2S-donating compds. The naturally occurring compds. discussed include, garlic, sulforaphane, erucin, and iberin. The synthetic H2S donors reviewed include, GYY4137; cysteine analogs; S-Pr cysteine, S-allyl cysteine, S-propargyl cysteine, and N-acetyl cysteine. Dithiolethione and its NSAID and other chimeras such as, L-DOPA, sildenafil, aspirin, diclofenac, naproxen, ibuprofen, indomethacin, and mesalamine have also been reviewed in detail. The newly reported NOSH-aspirin that releases both NO and H2S has also been discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xhs1KltrzP&md5=6ac384283ec1e20f8553cc4164cf490b
    32. 32

NOSH-aspirin (NBS-1120), a novel nitric oxide- and hydrogen sulfide-releasing hybrid is a potent inhibitor of colon cancer cell growth in vitro and in a xenograft mouse model Biochem. Biophys. Res.       Zhao, Y.; Biggs, T. D.; Xian, M. Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) releasing agents: chemistry and biological applications Chem. Commun. 2014, 50, 11788– 805 DOI: 10.1039/C4CC00968A
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      34
      Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) releasing agents: chemistry and biological applications
      Zhao, Yu; Biggs, Tyler D.; Xian, Ming
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2014), 50 (80), 11788-11805CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) is a newly recognized signaling mol. with very potent cytoprotective actions. The fields of H2S physiol. and pharmacol. have been rapidly growing in recent years, but a no. of fundamental issues must be addressed to advance our understanding of the biol. and clin. potential of H2S in the future. Hydrogen sulfide releasing agents (also known as H2S donors) have been widely used in these fields. These compds. are not only useful research tools, but also potential therapeutic agents. It is therefore important to study the chem. and pharmacol. of exogenous H2S and to be aware of the limitations assocd. with the choice of donors used to generate H2S in vitro and in vivo. In this review we summarized the developments and limitations of currently available donors including H2S gas, sulfide salts, garlic-derived sulfur compds., Lawesson's reagent/analogs, 1,2-dithiole-3-thiones, thiol-activated donors, photo-caged donors, and thioamino acids. Some biol. applications of these donors were also discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhtFSgtb7P&md5=420065ccbf3c5843a68f55d8555d07ca
    35. 35
      Song, Z. J.; Ng, M. Y.; Lee, Z.-W.; Dai, W.; Hagen, T.; Moore, P. K.; Huang, D.; Deng, L.-W.; Tan, C.-H. Hydrogen sulfide donors in research and drug development MedChemComm 2014, 5, 557– 570 DOI: 10.1039/c3md00362k
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      35
      Hydrogen sulfide donors in research and drug development
      Song, Zhi Jian; Ng, Mei Ying; Lee, Zheng-Wei; Dai, Weilu; Hagen, Thilo; Moore, Philip K.; Huang, Dejian; Deng, Lih-Wen; Tan, Choon-Hong
      MedChemComm (2014), 5 (5), 557-570CODEN: MCCEAY; ISSN:2040-2503. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) has recently emerged as an important biol. gasomediator as a result of numerous insightful studies. The use of H2S releasing compds. has attracted much attention as they can exert crucial effects on a wide range of cellular signaling processes. Some of these effects are potentially exploitable in terms of anti-inflammatory and anti-tumor effects, as well as precise ion-channel regulation, cardiovascular protection and oxidn. resistance. Unfortunately, the potential therapeutic effects of H2S are controversial due to conflicting published results regarding its effects on cellular activities arising, perhaps in part, from the use of different H2S donors. Therefore it is essential to review the most commonly used H2S releasing compds., some of which are currently in clin. trials along with their assocd. in vitro and/or in vivo biol. effects.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXms1WqsL0%253D&md5=a50223da36e68c4b2468244c65abe0aa
